NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will claims be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the File Hills Residential School for the Quarter ended March 31st 1947.

Principal L. L. Dobbin

Dated April 1st 1947

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at File Hills APR 8 1947

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita and days in quarter is calculated by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th inst. #111-1-5, with reference to receipts Nos. 11102, 11162, and 532 attached to Voucher 2886.

You observe that Mr. Deacon charges $25.00 per month for board of men working on the addition to the File Hills School, and that the Department is desirous to know whether he supplied, at his own expense, all the food supplies necessary to board these men.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Deacon did supply all the food necessary to board these men at his own expense, and did not draw from the Department's stores.

Mr. Deacon could very well have asked me to board the men elsewhere. It was an obligation to the Department that he took them in, and as a matter of fact he is out of pocket, as he could not board men at $25.00 per month. However, this is what he said he would do it at. I also know that it was a great inconvenience to him to have these men boarding at his house, but as I said before, it was a convenience to the Department, and that is why he did it.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to inform you that there is no regular fire alarm system in connection with the File Hills Boarding School, and this matter should be attended to without delay. I would respectfully request that I be authorized to spend $200.00 in installing two gongs together with the necessary wiring and work in connection therewith.

An extra fire escape pole is also required, to be erected at a low cost. I have not the figures at hand just now, but it would probably come to somewhere in the neighborhood of $200.00 to do this work.

I would also ask for your authority to purchase a couple of iron gates costing about $100.00.

There is a little extra work in connection with the setting up of a bell that was on the roof. This might be done for less than $25.00.

We have a carpenter at work now erecting the addition to the outside classroom, and if money is available I would have this work done by these men.

I would also ask for authority to purchase sufficient awning to fit over the screens on the new verandah that has been erected. I cannot say what this would cost, but $100.00 would be ample to cover this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,

Sir:

With reference to the amount allowed in the Estimates for out-buildings at the File Hills Residential School, I may inform you that the erection of an ice house, implement shed and poultry house is now being proceeded with.

More storage room is needed at this School. At the present time the Principal is using the old Principal's residence for storing his surplus clothing and other goods. This building is situated in the centre of what should be the children's play ground, and is anything but an ornament on the premises. It is my intention to give this building to an Indian and to build a small frame store house to take its place for storage purposes, if this meets with your approval. I may inform you that we will save a sufficient amount from the authority already granted to do this work, and it will not be necessary to ask for any additional funds.

I shall be glad to receive the Department's sanction to go on with this work.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your 306-11 A of the 9th instant, with reference to the building activity at the File Hills Indian Residential School. The henhouse and implement shed were authorized in addition to the classroom; but I note that you will be able to provide an ice house and a store room with the funds that were authorized for this school.

I wish to draw to your attention several expenditures which have been incurred at the File Hills Institution this fiscal year, in addition to the building programme, viz.: the gas engine, plumbing, boring well, fire escape, awning, screens and smaller items. In view of these expenditures, which were not voted, it is extremely desirable that no expense that is not absolutely necessary be incurred. You may proceed with the ice house and the store room, but the cost should be kept to a minimum consistent with efficiency.

Your obedient servant

A. F. MacKenzie,

Extract from Report of Inspector Murison on the File Hills Residential School - dated May 5th, 1926.

The main building, since the new addition was erected, has accommodation for 90 pupils. The building is well equipped for its purpose and a great improvement was noted since my last inspection. I found the building well kept and clean. The interior of the older portion requires repainting and decorating throughout. As it is some years since this was done, the paint has worn off in many places. I would suggest that the walls in the Girls' Playroom which is situated in the new addition should be wainscoted to protect the plaster. In a room used for this purpose, the walls are subject to hard knocks and unless wainscoted, it is a difficult matter to keep them clean for a height of four or five feet. The dining room has been extended and the extension should be wainscoted to make the appearance uniform. This work would not entail very much outlay.

I noted that two chairs for the Teachers are required.

An ice house, implement shed, store house and poultry house were built last year and require painting, as the work was done too late in the season to permit of this work being done.

WATER SUPPLY

The water supply is obtained from a well 128 ft. deep. This well has a capacity of about 25 barrels a day which is pumped into a 750 gallon pressure tank. Owing to the limited supply, it is necessary to pump almost continuously during about 15 hours of the day. This supply is not sufficient as it does not provide for any surplus in case of an emergency, such as fire.

In forwarding the above report Commissioner Graham in his letter No.306-9 of May 10th, 1926, states as follows:

You will note that this school has an accommodation for 90 pupils. The Inspector refers to certain interior decorating and re-painting. This should be done. I also think that the wainscoting referred to should be attended to.

This school is giving good satisfaction. They very seldom have any friction, and no complaints, for the simple reason that we have a practical man at the head of the institution. After Portage la Prairie, this, in my opinion, is the best boarding school we have.
Ottawa, May 17th, 1926.

Sir:

Relative to the two chairs which the Inspector states are required for the teachers' use, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of same, obtaining chairs of a good serviceable type. Please forward vouchers in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have representations from the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada to the effect that the interior of the Principal's Residence at the File Hills School needs decorating. The walls, I am told, are finished in white plaster, and have never been decorated during the two years since the residence has been built. The estimated cost of material is $100.00 and the labour about $50.00.

A request is also made for the painting of the outbuildings. The material will cost about $150.00 and the labour $80.00. These outbuildings were erected in the fall of 1925, and have not yet been painted. The lumber is checking badly and the buildings are consequently deteriorating.

Application is also made for a grant for painting and decorating the interior of the main building. The paint and varnish in the interior of this main building needs renewal and has not been decorated for the past twelve years. Some work, we are told, has been done by the school authorities, but lack of funds prevents the decorating of the whole building. The estimated cost of material is $1,200.00, and labour $400.00.

There is also a strong desire on the part of the management of this School that more land should be cleared. The estimated cost to clear one hundred acres is $1,500.00. Approximately fifty acres have been cleared by the school authorities and are ready to be broken. This breaking will have to be done by using an engine.

I trust the Department will see fit to make the necessary appropriation to have this land cleared and ploughed.

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

In the spring of last year I had measurements taken of the outbuildings at the File Hills School with a view to recommending their being painted, but owing to the circumstances which resulted in the difficulty of securing appropriations, I left the matter in abeyance.

FARM & GARDEN.

There is 75 acres under cultivation; last year their crop included 25 acres of Barley, 35 acres of Oats, 8 acres of Potatoes and 15 acres of summerfallow, the balance being used for garden. The potatoes were a short crop last year and they will have to buy about 150 bushels to meet their requirements. The garden provided ample vegetables for their use. The total acreage set aside for this school is 413. The portion not under cultivation is largely covered with scrub and is broken up with small hay sloughs. It was planned to have this land cleared and brought under cultivation last year, but owing to certain conditions this could not be done.

In conclusion, I would say that conditions at this school continue to be very satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Water Supply (Cont'd)

Upon examining the pump in operation that it was only pumping a percentage of its capacity. The pressure tank is, in my opinion, too small to provide a surplus of water for an emergency. An item of $1,000.00 was placed in last year's estimates to provide a supply of water for washing and flushing purposes. It is proposed to dig a seepage reservoir at the edge of the lake, which is a short distance in front of the school, and pipe the water to the school for this purpose. If this was done, it would be necessary to have a separate pressure tank and connections so that there would be no danger of getting this water mixed with that used from the well for drinking purposes.

Pupilage.

There are 89 pupils enrolled, 36 boys and 53 girls, all of whom were in residence, with the exception of 2 girls who are in High School and 2 boys and 2 girls absent on account of sickness. The children were well dressed, looked clean and well nourished.

The staff at this school appear to be quite competent in their different departments. I noted some changes since my last visit. A new Farming Instructor has been appointed and from what I hear, he is reputed to be the best they have had at this school.

Stock.

Their stock includes 15 Holstein cows, 2 bulls, 4 heifers, 7 calves, 9 head of horses and also 35 head of poultry. The cattle are a good type of Holstein. They had already 7 cows freshened this Spring. The herd provides ample milk for the use of the children.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection made at the File Hills Boarding School by Mr. Inspector Murison on the 12th instant.

The matter of repairs and painting has been dealt with in a separate letter.

With regard to the water supply, it seems to me that something will have to be done. The proposal to dig a seepage reservoir at the edge of the lake and connect it up with the pressure system to be used for washing and flushing purposes might be followed. This would leave the limited supply of water in the well for drinking purposes. The cost of this would be about $1000.00, or perhaps a little more, and I should be glad to have your authority to proceed with the work.

The pupilage at this school is good, although we could take in eleven more if they could be had. I understand from the Principal that he is going to start out on a recruiting trip shortly.

Nothing has yet been done to clear land at the school. It is most difficult to get men who will undertake this sort of work. I am hoping, however, to get something done this year. The funds, I suppose will be available, as they were not used last year, and a re-vote was asked for.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,

Sir,

In reply to your letter lll-1-5, dated the 21st instant, in connection with your enquiry with regard to fitting up the old interpreter's house at the Agency for the use of Indians visiting File Hills School.

The house referred to is an old log house that was sheeted outside with siding and has a shingle roof. It has not been used for at least ten years, consequently it is in a bad state for repairs. The windows and doors would all have to be re-newed and it would also have to have new floors, the roof repaired, new stairs and something done to the walls as all the plaster has fallen off. I estimate that it would cost about $350.00 to do the above mentioned work.

There is at the Agency a small house that was built a few years ago for the destitute Indians who needed extra care. It did not prove a success as the old people would not stay there. It is not a great distance from the School, less than a half a mile, but if this is considered too far, it could easily be moved. It is in good shape, but there was only two ply of boards put on when it was built. I think this building would be far more suitable for the purpose mentioned. If it is, I recommend that it be sheeted inside the studding, the cost of which would be about $100.00. There are some furnishings in the place but it should have some more, such as pots and pans, blankets, bedding, etc. These should not cost more than $40.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the File Hills Residential School, stating that the engine which operates the plant at that institution has not had an expert overhauling since it was installed in October, 1925, and asks if arrangements could be made to have this done before the heavy winter load is placed on the plant.

Is this an expenditure which the Department should bear? It seems to me that the school authorities should arrange for this service.

Principals of residential schools are constantly calling upon the Department to bear expenditures which I think should be borne by them. The correspondence entailed in attending to these matters involves a great deal of work, which might be obviated if the school authorities were given to understand that the cost of the upkeep of the plants installed at residential schools should be borne by themselves and not by the Department, as that I understand is the policy of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

The makers of this Machine have discontinued manufacture of this particular model, in fact it has been obsolete for the past 5 years, and we find it is impossible to obtain repairs or spare parts to keep the machine in good running order, and I was wondering if the Department would give us a little financial assistance in procuring another Machine. We could purchase a "Zenith" Model E for the sum of $290.00 F.O.B. Regina, this machine is an excellent one for the purpose and will give many years of satisfactory service. Yours truly

REGINA, SASK. Nov. 8th, 1929

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter that I received from Mr. F. Rhodes, Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School. You will note that Mr. Rhodes is making a request that the Department pay half the cost of a Moving Picture Machine which he would like to buy. I know that the machine which I gave Mr. Rhodes has been a source of great pleasure to the children of the school, and many of the older Indians have been in the habit of going there once a week and having a regular picture show in the outside classroom, so that if you could see your way clear to meet his request it would be greatly appreciated, not only by the pupils, but also by the people on the reserve. This school has always given good satisfaction and the cost of operation has been small compared with most schools. I doubt whether anything has been given to them in the way of equipment for games, so that this request, in my opinion, is a reasonable one, and I am sure if it is possible to do so you will authorize the expenditure.

Yours very truly,

V. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, November 15th, 1929.

Sir,

I have your 306-11A of the 8th instant, enclosing copy of a communication from the Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School in which he requests that the Department pay half the cost of the purchase of a moving picture machine for the use of the school.

In this connection I would point out that it is not the policy of the Department to provide equipment of this nature for Indian schools. However, in view of the report of the Principal and yourself as to the service which this machine will give to the pupils and Indians, the Department will make an exception in this case and will provide half the cost of same. The Principal should arrange for the payment of the entire cost of the picture machine, obtaining a receipt, in duplicate. This you should forward to the Department attached to a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, for one-half the cost, when a refund of this amount will be made to the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

There is an outside closet provided for boys at the north east end of the boys' playground, and a similar convenience for the girls situated to the south of the school and close to the lake. Remarks and explanations covering items on page 15. Boarding

Cattle Barn 18 x 80

There is not sufficient room to house the cattle at the School and it is proposed to build a lean-to to the barn 18 x 80. This will supply ample accommodation. There will be ten double cow stalls with feed alley. The floor is to be of cement. It is intended to cut a door to enable the cattle to be fed from the main barn. The studding of the outside will be nine feet and inside 14 feet. It is estimated the lumber, cement, hardware, etc., will cost $950, and the labour $350. I have charged the item from a lean-to to a separate barn which is far more advisable.

Fencing

The fencing around the School is worn out. It is estimated the material that is wire, posts and stables will cost $100. I did not estimate for labour as I considered the staff and boys should be able to do that themselves.

New cement floor for kitchen

The floor in the kitchen is badly worn out and it is thought that a cement floor would be the most serviceable for that room. The material would cost $25.00 and the labour $15.00. The gravel would be obtained by the School.

New hardwood floor for hall in basement

The floor is worn out and needs replacing. The material, that is hardwood and nails would cost $250 and the labour $50.00 $75.00.

Painting garage, store house and pump house

These three buildings need painting. The paint and labour will cost $100.

Addition to chicken house 16 x 30

The chicken house they have at present will only accommodate 50 chickens and it is desired to increase the flock to 150, which I do not consider will be too many.

Wainscoting in Hospital wing.

The plaster in the hospital wing around the bottom of the walls is getting badly broken and cracked. It is thought that putting on wainscoting instead of replastering it will be more serviceable. A separate building should be built to accommodate the cattle. A lean-to will cut off ventilation if built on the existing barn. The additional cost will be small. All items asked for in this sheet have been gone into thoroughly and should be approved.

Dear Sir:

Following your instructions, we made a trip to the File Hill School, with a view of gathering information, so as to report to you on water conditions, re the supply for the School.

We went very carefully into all the details, with your Mr. Dodds and Mr. Rhodes. The supply at the present time is mostly taken from the lake, and we certainly were very much surprised to find that this lake had receded approximately ten feet, during the past year, thus leaving only about four feet of water at the deepest point. During the cold winter months this lake will now freeze to the bottom, which means the water supply will be cut off.

We then made a further investigation, and find that you have a well near the School which supplies a very limited amount of water, and could not take care of any reasonable portion of your daily supply. We therefore recommended to your Mr. Dodds, and Mr. Rhodes, that the only solution of overcoming the difficulty, would be to drill a well, and in accordance with your request, that we give special quotations on account of economic conditions, we wish to submit the following, which is very much below any other figures we have ever quoted on a guaranteed proposition.

We would be willing to drill a well at the File Hill School, using 5" Screw and Socket Well Casing, and Drive Shoe, and would be prepared to drill this well to a depth of at least 450 feet, if necessary. We would guarantee to supply 3000 gallons of water per twenty-four hours, for the sum of Eleven hundred dollars ($1,100.00).

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., November 21st, 1931.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

The question of a water supply for the File Hills Residential School has been further investigated, and from what I can gather there is a great danger of all the lakes around File Hills freezing to the bottom this year. The lake near the school, where the water supply is obtained at the present time, will certainly freeze to the bottom. I suggested to the Department, failing the securing of a well, that the only alternative would be to haul water. The Principal of the school is very much opposed to this scheme, and I believe the Agent has come around to the feeling that it would be impracticable, especially in view of the fact that the lake from which it was proposed to haul the water will, in all likelihood, freeze to the bottom, and then there would be no other alternative but to close the school.

Having had all phases of the situation placed before me, I decided to send Mr. Thom, of McPherson and Thom, Regina, who are agents for the Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Co., also well drillers, out to the File Hills Agency to investigate matters, and was surprised to receive from him a most excellent offer. I enclose herewith a copy of Mr. Thom's letter. There is a possibility, if they go down 450 ft., of securing a good supply of water. We have, in the past, never gone down anything like this depth, and we are only called upon to pay $275.00, part of the actual expenses, if water is not obtained, and $1,100.00 if we secure a supply of water amounting to 3,000 gals. every twenty-four hours, which, of course, if obtained, will be a great thing for this school. The present water supply arrangements at this school, at the best, are very unsatisfactory, and the water is not fit for domestic consumption; the only supply for this purpose is obtained from a shallow source.

Dear Dr Scott:

I am in receipt of your circular letter of the 5th inst having reference to Fire protection in Indian Residential Schools, and in reply wish to take up one or two matters relative to this subject in connection with this School.

In paragraph 5 definite instructions are laid down to the effect that a night watchman must be employed in all Schools where the interior is of frame construction, this building having been erected in 1910 is of this type of construction, I presume that the Department intends the Church authorities or the Principal in charge of the School to assume responsibility for the appointing of such a night watchman; I bring up this question because it is not always possible to pay extra salaries out of School funds, and sometimes the Church authorities are loath to assume this extra financial burden, more particularly in times like the present, in this connection also I would advise that it will be necessary to install a time clock in the School so that a check can be kept on the movements of the night watchman, for no matter how reliable a man may be there is always the possibility that he may be inclined to shirk duty, especially during the night hours when there is no one around to keep a check upon him, would the Department be disposed to supply and install this time clock?

In the matter of Fire prevention; I believe that our equipment is adequate to cope with small outbreaks, regarding the Fire escapes; the escape at this School are of the Iron pipe type, leading from the Sleeping balconies to the Verandah numbering them in all, to clear the School it is necessary for the Pupils and Staff to parade in the sleeping balconies, drop to the verandah, proceed along the verandah for distances of 35 feet in each case to the steps leading to the ground, I have conferred with Mr Indian Agent Dodds re this matter and we are of the opinion that this is not a very safe procedure as if the front of the building were to be on fire the escapes would be practically cut off preventing anyone from reaching the ground safely, I believe Mr Dodds is also writing the Department re this matter.

I fully realize the huge responsibility resting upon the Principal's of the Residential Schools, and assure you that everything is done at this School to safeguard life and property consistent with the facilities at hand.

Yours truly,

With reference to your Circular letter 1-1-5, dated the 5th instant, in connection with fire prevention in the Indian Schools.

I visited File Hills School yesterday and went into everything in connection with fire prevention and fire escapes in accordance with your instructions.

The fire escapes at File Hills School are the pole kind. That is an iron pole runs from the balcony which adjoins the dormitory to the verandah, down which the children slide. This is fairly efficient but there are several features that I thought it would be better to bring to your attention.

There are a number of young children in the school around seven and though they slide down the pole fairly well in practice they might let go of the pole and suffer a serious fall under excitement.

The bottom of the pole comes on the verandah. If a fire occurred in the room close to the pole it is possible that flames might come through the window and make it impossible to use the escape.

There is a trap door on the balcony covering up the hole down which the children slide. This trap door opens upwards and it is conceivable that in a panic the children might crowd on the door and make it impossible for anyone to open it. I made enquiries regarding this and found it used to open downwards but one of the staff in trying to open it fell through and was seriously injured.

In case you consider the escape in use should be changed I would recommend those spiral escapes similar to those used in the public schools in the cities. I understand they are rather expensive and I am only suggesting this in case you think a new system is necessary.

There are chemical fire extinguishers and also a water system for use in a fire at this school. The staff have been told how to operate the fire extinguishers and how to operate the water system. They however do not have any actual practice with the water system. I would recommend that the water system be actually tried out about once a month so that we could be sure everything is in working order and that the staff can do what they are supposed to do without delay. I would also like the Principal instructed to inform me when this practice is to take place so that I could be present and report on it.

File Hills School is of frame construction with a brick veneer. They have no night watchman.
They have a gardener at the school who can do very little at his job during the winter. I think he could do the night watchman's duties during winter and I think the school should be able to pay for a man during the summer months out of the government grant.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your 111-1-5, dated the 22nd ultimo, I beg to advise that I visited File Hills School on the 29th February as Mr. Rhodes had informed they were going to have a fire drill and practice with the fire fighting system.

The children were marched upstairs to the dormitory and three and a half minutes after the alarm was sounded the school had been emptied.

They then had a practice with the water system and every hose was tried out and found to be in working order. I noticed however that the water when it first came out of the hose was very much discoloured due no doubt to the corrosion of the pipes. This cleaned out immediately and then the water came in a clear strong stream. I think it wise to have these practices regularly so that everyone will be thoroughly conversant with their duties in case of an actual fire.

With regard to your suggestion that a steel stair escapes should be erected at the back. This would give an additional avenue of escape in case of fire and I think myself that it would be as well if one were provided. Mr. Rhodes however is not in favour of it as he is of the opinion that the pupils would use it for getting away from the dormitory and other undesirable purposes, at night. This is true but the same objection can be advanced with regard to any fire escape.

To prevent the improper use of the fire escapes by the pupils is a problem which confronts every school principal but I do not think it is a good way to solve this by limiting the means of escape or blocking the fire escapes.

Your obedient servant,
Indian agent.

DUTIES OF THE NIGHT WATCHMAN.

It shall be the duty of the Night Watchman to make a tour of the Building every hour between the hours of 10 O'clock P.M. to 6 O'clock A.M in the Summer and from 10 O'clock P.M to 7 O'clock A.M in the Winter and commencing at No 1 station to punch his clock at each consecutive station finishing with No 10, while on his patrol he will see that everything is in order throughout the building.

In case of Fire the watchman will sound the alarm and will assist in evacuating the building, afterwards rendering what service is necessary to assist in putting out the Fire.

It will also be the duty of the night watchman to Fire the steam boilers during his tour of duty, to light the Fires in the Kitchen range, Bakeshop, and Laundry at 5-30 A.M in the Summer and 6-30 A.M in the winter.

On completion of each days tour of duty the night watchman will hand his time clock, together with a report covering the period of duty completed, to the Principal or other member of Staff designated by the Principal and will receive his time clock each evening at 9-45 from the Principal or other member of Staff to be designated, all stations must be registered when going on duty and when completing duty, keys to the padlocks on Station boxes must be surrendered each day with the Time clock.

If during the period of duty any or all stations are not registered within the hour the night watchman must give a detailed explanation as to why the station or stations were not registered, this is very important.

Dear Sir:

Attached hereto please find report for this School for the fiscal year ending March 31st 1933.

I would like to make a few observations in support of some statements made in the report;— The outside Toilets at this School were erected in 1922 at which time we had an attendance of 65 Pupils, these toilets are of the pit type and have been moved so many times that the ground has become polluted and we find it practically impossible to locate them on unpolluted ground, they are in a delapidated condition and very difficult to keep sanitary, this condition was brought to the attention of Mr W.M. Graham, then Indian Commissioner, in August 1931, Mr Graham communicated with the Department regarding this matter and suggested that we could manage with the present toilets, this we have done to the present time but we have now come to the point when something must be done to bring our outside toilet facilities up to date, we now have 85 pupils on the register or a 30% increase over the pupilage in 1923, I would suggest that buildings be erected of the moveable box or Pail type, a rough estimate of the cost of these would be about $175.00 for material and labour.

With reference to the Barn;— We have accommodation in the Cow barn for 16 Head of cattle, this number was sufficient to supply the requirements for 65 pupils, since the increase in pupilage however we find that more milk is required hence a larger herd must be maintained, we now have 32 head including Cows and calves and to accommodate this number we have utilized every inch of space in both the Cow barn and the Horse stable even to the harness rooms and feed stalls and then the cattle were considerably overcrowded, I feel that if the Department could provide us with an addition to the barn we could house the herd in the Winter very comfortably and get better results from them.

I realise that funds are very scarce but I would greatly appreciate any consideration given to these suggestions.

Yours truly,

Sir:

If new toilets are erected, at a cost of $175, it would leave only the sum of $725 for other repairs and improvements. I would request that you inform the Department definitely concerning the new toilets, giving particulars as to size and type, the materials required and the approximate cost of any labour other than that which can be performed by the staff of the school. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 111-1-5, dated the 3rd inst with regard to building repairs and improvements required by File Hills Residential School. I have gone into this matter with the principal of the school, as directed.

He requires a lean-to addition made to the barn for the purpose of housing his cattle for which he has not sufficient room. The building would be 45 feet long, 18 feet wide, 9 feet high at the low end and 12 feet high on the side nearest the barn. It would contain 6 double stalls, or enough room for 12 animals. It would be double boarded, the first being of shiplap and the other of siding. The floor would be of concrete. It is estimated that the bill of material enclosed herewith would be sufficient to do the job.

He also required two outside toilets, one for the boys and one for the girls. He proposes to build a toilet with accommodation for six people in each and with movable boxes. It is estimated the bill of material enclosed herewith will be sufficient for one toilet.

Mr. Rhodes has also asked for sufficient wire and posts to fence around the playground and school. The wire and post would cost $28.00 and the labour would be provided by the school.

The material for the root house is being purchased at a cost of $100.00

The main halls both on the first floor and basement need kalsomining. The labour and material for this would cost $35.00

They will require new batteries for their electric light plant which will cost $200.00.

I would therefore request incumbrance requisitions for the following:

Addition to barn at File Hills Residential School. Material and labour $310.00
Outside toilets 2, labour and material $140.00
Posts and pipe fencing for playground $28.00
Kalsomining basement hall, main hall and dining room. Material and labour $35.00
New batteries for lighting plant $200.00

It is understood that incumbrance requisition for new root house for the school has already been sent to Mr. W. Hurison.

I would ask you to return the bills of material for the addition to the barn and the toilets after you have examined them.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to forward herewith File Hills Agency Voucher No. 366 in favor of Potts and Miller, Ltd., amounting to $21.05 for repairs for the hot water boiler in the File Hills Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that the Poultry House at the File Hills Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on the morning of the 4th, instant.

The cause of the fire was seemingly from an overheated stove pipe or a spark from the stove, as the building was being used for a breeding pen and the use of a stove was necessary to prevent the eggs chilling.

I beg to recommend the replacement of this building, size 16' x 32' x 8', the cost of material and labour I estimate at $300.00, as a new building could be erected on the old foundation.

Trusting this will meet with your approval,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, reporting the destruction, by fire, of the poultry house at the File Hills Indian Residential School. The Department would like to be informed if there was any carelessness in the operation of the stove. It is thought that, if it had been properly attended to, there would not have been any danger of the pipe becoming over-heated or a spark escaping from the stove.

Sir,

Since June, 1932, the Department has been allowing $30.00 a month towards the salary of a night watchman at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

As our appropriation for this purpose is limited and as we have recently received requests for allowances towards night watchmen's salaries at several other Indian residential schools that had not previously received same, it has been found necessary to place all residential schools on the same basis and only allow a grant towards the night watchman's salary for a period not exceeding seven months. Consequently, the allowance for the services of the night watchman at the File Hills Indian Residential School will be discontinued from April 30th, 1935.

Payment of this allowance will be resumed from October 1st, 1935, and will be continued until April 30th, 1936, a period of seven months, during which time the amount of $40.00 will be allowed. If the Principal so desires, you may forward a voucher at the end of each month for the period during which the allowance is made.

I would suggest that part of this sum be used to rebuild the Poultry House and the remainder used to paint the Outbuildings as far as possible, my reason for this suggestion is that the Main building is looking very shabby indeed and is not a very good advertisement either for the Department, the Agency or the School, the main building has not been painted since 1929, 6 years ago, and I would stress the need for this work to be done this year without fail, the outbuildings with one or two exceptions could go for another year, the balance of $100.00 or any amount left over after the Poultry house has been erected could be used to paint the buildings requiring it the most."

Sir:-

I beg to advise the Department that I visited the File Hills Residential School on the 13th instant and made an examination of the buildings. The school building has not been repainted for a number of years and is very badly in need of repainting. If it is left much longer the building will deteriorate.

I found the balconies in urgent need of repairs. I do not consider them in their present condition safe, as dry rot has set in along the sills. I asked Mr. Rhodes to get a carpenter to examine the balconies and prepare an estimate of the cost. I am today in receipt of this estimate which is as follows;— lumber and material $69.35, labour and hardware $65.00, 75 yards of 12 oz. canvas duck $27.00, making a total of $161.35.

I may inform you that these balconies are used as sleeping balconies and the outer walls, in addition to screen net, are enclosed with canvas. This gives a free circulation of air. The canvas is badly torn and should be renewed. I would recommend that, if possible, this expenditure be authorized.

Referring to Departmental letter No. 111-1-5, dated the last instant, advising me regarding the amounts provided in the Appropriation for the current fiscal year for painting, repairs, and equipment at the File Hills Residential School. I beg to advise you that immediately upon receipt of your letter I got in touch with Mr. Dodds, the Indian Agent, and the Principal of the school and later on we had a conference together regarding the work.

1. Regarding the painting of the main and outside buildings we are of the opinion that it would be advisable to employ a competent house-painter and have the work done by day labour. We can employ some Indian labour, particularly on the outbuildings and I would be glad if the Department could authorize me at once to proceed with the work along these lines. I may advise you that I received information that the price of paint was going to advance after the 1st of July, so I took it upon myself to obtain competitive prices from firms on the approved list hereunder and purchased the paint and had it forwarded on to the school. I trust this will meet with your approval. I obtained a very reasonable price on the paint.

2. With reference to the repairs to the verandah and balconies of the main building, I may say that this work is being proceeded with. We have engaged the services of a local carpenter, Mr. Haste who has done most of our carpentry work at the File Hills Agency for some years now. He is a very reliable man and we may find it advisable to engage him to supervise the general repair work at the school, including the painting.

3. With reference to the 32 volt batteries for the lighting plant, I may advise you that the plant in use now is a Delco Ironclad 160 Ampere hour battery. This battery is sulphating badly. There is no immediate hurry for replacing this battery until about the 1st of November when the load will increase to practically the maximum capacity of the battery. It would not be safe to depend on this battery after that time. During the winter months they have from 65 to 70 ampere hour loads and as the capacity of this battery is only 72 amperes, you will readily understand that the battery would require to be in good shape in order to stand up and the present battery could not be relied upon.

4. With reference to the fifty mattresses for the pupils' beds for which the sum of $250.00 is allowed, I may advise you

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
that the size of the mattresses required is 3 ft. x 6 ft.

Mr. Rhodes asks for a standard layer felt mattress with heavy brown duck covering. I have obtained quotations from the Parkhill Bedding Company and Simmons Limited, both of whom are on the approved list here. The Parkhill Bedding quote $5.75 F.O.B. Balcarres and Simmons Limited quote $4.92 each, plus the Sales Tax, which would amount to 38¢, bringing the cost to $5.31 each. If the Department do not have to pay the Sales Tax their price would come within the appropriation, otherwise it will be exceeded by $16.80. I would recommend that the Simmons mattress be purchased.

I would be glad to receive authority to proceed with the work at File Hills as above outlined. It is important that the work should be proceeded with with the least possible delay, as it is desirable that it should be done while the children are absent on their vacation during the month of July.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that the Delco lighting plant at the File Hills Indian Residential School is out of commission.

When the plant was taken down and examined, it was found that a bolt holding the connecting rod cap had broken thus permitting the connecting rod to lash about freely in the cylinder and the crankcase.

The crankcase, cylinder, connecting rod, piston with piston pin and rings and crankshaft were found to be damaged and will require replacing. Regina is the nearest place to have this work carried out.

These repairs and replacements will cost approximately $250.00.

The school meanwhile are running on an auxiliary lighting system but this plant is not adequate to take care of their requirements.

Should this meet with your approval, I should appreciate your wiring me so that this plant can be put into working operation again with as little delay as possible.

Your obedient servant,

October 7th, 1937.

Dear Sir:-

Re piping water from school to barn
File Hills Indian Residential School.

I have the honor to reply to your letter 306-11 A.U.
of the 30th ultimo, with regard to the above.

Dec to state I have also received a letter from the
Principal, Mr. F. Rhodes, referring to the above.

Mr. Rhodes' letter states that the distance from the
school to the barn is 280 feet, that a trench would have to be
dug 2 ft. wide and 8 ft. deep, that 1" piping would cost $55.14
F.O.B Regina, and he estimated the labour at $70.00 to $75.00.

In the past the school have winter watered their
stock from a slough in front of the school, but this is now
absolutely dry, as is other sloughs in the near vicinity. Mr.
Rhodes is quite certain that their deep well would give them
a sufficient supply of water if it were piped to the barn,
and they have the machinery to take care of this. Other than
this they would have to fill their water tank at the school
haul it to the barn, with the danger that it might freeze
and ruin the tank.

The Department have authorized me to purchase 200
sacks of flour, 70 of this is for the warehouse ration use,
and 25 is for our winter firewood purchase, leaving 105 sacks
for relief. It was my idea that if relief in flour was issued
to have the Indians bring wood, which later could be sold and
a refund make to the Department.

I do not think the 280' trench can be dug for $75.00
my Estimate would be nearer $140.00, however possibly we could
put a value of $3.50 on the flour and pay the Indians at a
rate of $1.75 a day for digging, which would mean two days work
per Indian for one sack of flour. If this work were started
on this scheme, as some of the Indians would come from quite a
distance, we would pretty nearly have to give them something
for a noon-day meal, possibly some bacon and tea and I am doubt-
ful if we have enough in our warehouse for this.

See Page 2
Dear Sir:-

I beg to submit attached letter from Mr. Dodds, Agent File Hills.

In explanation I might say that Mr. Rhodes discussed this matter with me some time ago and I wrote Mr. Dodds for a report suggesting that if relief had to be given it might be undertaken as a relief measure.

I have circulated all our agents asking that they require all able bodied Indians to whom rations or clothing are issued to require that they either supply wood or do other work, which would be of value to the Department in return, as I am convinced we must impress upon them that they must work for what they receive.

This work would cost $55.14 and freight for piping and Mr. Rhodes estimates $75 for digging trench. The digging could be taken care of by flour and clothing.

If the funds are available I would suggest the piping and $75 for trench be authorized with the understanding that if it cost more Mr. Rhodes would finance it, also any meals required for the Indians.

In considering this the question of what effect this additional drain will have upon the present well must be considered. There is sufficient water for both purposes at present and no doubt should they have to haul the water they will get it from the well. Should the well not furnish enough they will look for another source for the stock. Would they do this should the connections be made or would they demand that the Department go to the expense of deepening the present well or boring a new one in order that the supply would be sufficient without hauling it, I am afraid of this.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources.

Thos. Robertson,

Ottawa, March 15, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, provision was made in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 for an amount of $300.00 to replace the batteries at the File Hills School and also an amount of $500.00 for painting and repairs. This makes a total of $800.00 for new equipment, repairs and improvements at the File Hills School. It is not necessary to expend the money in the exact manner in which it was mentioned in the estimates.

Please let me know for what purposes the Principal considers the amount available should be expended, and if requesting any material or equipment full particulars should be supplied in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Sir:

I have discussed the matter of manual and vocational training with Mr. Dodds, Agent, File Hills, and Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School.

After discussing the matter, they advise that they would require, for the purpose of carrying on this work, a building 18 x 32, 12 ft. wall, with cement foundation and floor, and they estimate that it would cost about $50.00 for lumber, hardware, painting and labour, to erect the building. The building would be divided into two shops, one for carpentry, the other for implement repairs and paint shop, with a loft above for storage of working and finished materials. Some plain ordinary tools would be required, such as what the Indian would use on the Reserve—hammers, rules, pliers, screwdrivers, etc., and while the school have about two complete sets of such tools on hand, Mr. Rhodes stated about another two sets would be required, costing around $50.00 for the two sets.

Their idea would be to train the boys in carpentry, painting, implement repairs, gas engines, electrical engineering, and animal husbandry. No extra staff would be required.

Mr. Dodds goes on to say that he presumes, if this work was started, the Department would supply a certain amount of working material which would be required, such as lumber, paint, paint brushes, hardware, etc., and that once the work was in actual operation, material could mostly be supplied from the sale of the completed work, consisting of tables, benches, stools, chairs, cupboards, etc., which could easily be sold on the Reserve at cost or a little above it.

Submitted for your consideration.

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

In this connection I would refer you to my letter of the 15th instant in which you were advised of the amount provided in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 for the purchase of equipment and repairs and improvements at the File Hills school.

Dear Sir:

Vocational Training Building,
File Hills School.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Dodds, Agent at File Hills, with regard to using this year's appropriation for the erection of a vocational training building. Ottawa,
April 19, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in connection with the erection of a vocational training building at the File Hills Indian residential school.

The cost of the material and labour to do the work recommended in your letter of March 31 amounts to $494.50. Only $500.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at this school and this amount is practically exhausted. In addition, of course, we are purchasing the batteries at an approximate cost of $300.00.

However, in view of your recommendation it has been decided to take $400.00 from a small unallotted item in our appropriation. It should be distinctly understood, however, that no further amount can be allowed for repairs, improvements or purchase of new equipment at the File Hills residential school during the current fiscal year.

Please let me have detailed information regarding the manner in which the $400.00 is to be expended. If any material is required the necessary information should be supplied in order that purchase may be made by our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

R. A. Roey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your #114-1-5 of June 5th, Repairs and Alterations, File Hills Residential School.

There is apparently a misunderstanding with regard to the payment of the labour.

In your letter #114-1-5 of April 19th, you advised that there was only $500.00 provided for repairs and improvements at this school, but that in view of my recommendations, it had been decided to take $400.00 from a small unallotted item for the building of the vocational training building, making a total of $900.00.

Our understanding of this was that the Department would pay the cost of the material and labour for the repairs and re-decorating of the school to an amount not in excess of $500.00, and that an additional amount of $400.00 would be granted for the construction of the vocational building, the school to pay all other costs and labour necessary for the erection of that building.

Under my #306-11A of April 26th I forwarded a requisition covering the material required for the erection of the vocational building, amounting to $464.50, and advised that if the Department would pay $400.00 of this bill, the school would pay the balance of $64.50, purchase the necessary hardware, and pay for the labour and operating costs until the end of the present fiscal year.

It was not my understanding, nor the understanding of the school authorities, that they would pay the labour costs of the repairs and improvements, and I am very sorry if anything in my letter gave you a different understanding.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to reply to letter No.306-11A of the 12th instant, regarding the batteries for the lighting plant of the File Hills Indian Residential School.

Having talked the matter over with Mr. Rhodes, I beg to advise that the plant at this school is a Delco 5 K.W. with a 72 ampere capacity (charging rate). The maximum load on this plant in winter time is 65 ampere. From past experience a light battery only lasts one year at this school whereas the Ironclad (heavy duty) batteries last from 2 to 2½ years. For the past six years Ironclad batteries have been supplied this school, and before that two sets of a lighter battery were hooked-up together but this was found too costly. The school lighting plant operates 7 to 8 hours in the winter time and 4 hours in the summer daily. In Mr. Rhodes opinion if the Globelite people were to see his plant the guarantee would be voided immediately.

A 15 plate battery is required, and I enclose herewith sheet from the Globelite Batteries Limited and have marked in blue pencil the battery to give service to this school.

Trusting this will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

G. A. Dodds,
Indian Agent.

Thomas Robertson, Esq.
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Federal Building,
Regina,

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your #111-1-5 of June 8, Batteries,
File Hills Indian Residential School

I have taken this matter up with Mr. Dodds and Mr. Rhodes, and am attaching copy of the letter received from Mr. Dodds. You will note that it is Mr. Rhodes' opinion that if the Globelite people were to see his plant, the guarantee would be void.

On Wednesday of this week, Mr. Lazorka, of the Engineering Department, Prince Albert National Park, called at my office on his way to the Qu'Appelle Agency, having received instructions from his Department to visit that Agency and report on the electric light plant there. I took advantage of Mr. Lazorka's visit to take him to File Hills and get his advice. Mr. Lazorka is apparently of the same opinion as Mr. Rhodes—that the load is too heavy for the batteries supplied, and under those conditions the seven-year guarantee would be practically valueless.

Mr. Dodds attached to his letter a Globelite pamphlet showing the different types of batteries. The type considered by him and Mr. Rhodes to be the most suitable for the school is marked in blue pencil. I have shown this to Mr. Lazorka and he confirms Mr. Dodds' advice.

With regard to the guarantee given by this company, I might point out that this guarantee is given with the understanding that the batteries are the proper size and capacity for the duty they are required to perform. In view of all the information I have been able to secure, I am satisfied that the batteries supplied do not meet those requirements and that the guarantee would be practically valueless. In view of this, and of the fact that we are building a workshop at this school, where additional light will be required, I would recommend that the batteries asked for, as marked on the attached pamphlet, be supplied.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

COPY OF REPORT ON DEEP WELL AT THE FILE HILLS INDIAN RESID.
SCHOOL. BALCARRS. SASK.

Depth of Well when drilled. 325 feet. 1929.
Height of water from base of Well. 240 feet.
Size of Casing 5 inch.
Size of Pump used up to Sept.1940. 2 inch Pipe with 1 - 13/16th. Cylinder, Wood rod. Length of Pump 140 feet.

In September 1940 the Pump pipe stripped at the first joint from the top permitting about 120 feet of Pipe to fall to the bottom of the well, a distance of approximately 180 feet and it is considered that the pipe falling this extreme distance has penetrated the mud and sand at the bottom of the well to a considerable distance probably splitting or buckling the pipe. I engaged the services of Mr. J. McCashin of Lipton to assist us in pulling the pipe out of the well. Mr. McCashin is an experienced well-driller, a taper tap was procured and the necessary pipe to connect with the pipe in the well. Several times they were able to get a good hold of the pipe but when pressure was applied in pulling the pipe the taper-tap would slip off. Pressure was applied by means of a clamp and two screw jacks. By this means they were enabled to exert an even pressure of considerable force, in spite of this we were forced to abandon the attempt to pull the pipe.

A smaller pump of 1 inch diameter with a 1 - 13/16th. cylinder was then installed being put down to a depth of 200 feet. This was satisfactory for a short time when it was found necessary to increase the depth of the pump to 260 feet. This was necessary due to the fact that the old pump pipe had shut off part of the stream in the bottom of the well and the well would not give us sufficient quantity of water for our requirements. At this depth the well gave us just sufficient supply for the needs of the School (N.B. we have not been able to supply the stock since last Fall).

On February 27th, of this year it was noted that a high wind was prevailing and the water in the well became badly discoloured having a reddish colour. On February 28th, the amount of supply dwindled to such an extent that it was found necessary to pull the pump. On examination of the Cylinder it was found that the leathers had become badly worn. New leathers were installed and the pump replaced in the well. After operating for about 8 hours it was noted that the pump was not delivering water, and the pump was pulled again the following day when it was noted that the pipe from the cylinder for a distance of approximately 24 feet had become filled with sand. It was then decided to take off about 40 feet of pipe and re-install the pump. This was done on March 4th, to-date the pump has been operating satisfactorily, giving us a sufficient supply to take care of the requirements of the School (other than the stock tanks) however with the amount of sand which has come into the well it is not possible to state that the supply of water will be available for any indefinite period. If it were possible to remove the old pump pipe from the well and the well thoroughly cleaned out I am of the opinion that the supply would be adequate for our requirements.
One feature is noted, before the water became discoloured on February 27th, the water obtained from the well would be quite clear for a few hours, but would then become discoloured, having a red colour and would stain any utensil in which it was placed. Since the above date the water has been quite clear and does not discolour so readily on coming in contact with the air.

I am of the opinion that a new stream or vein has broken through. This would account for the excessive quantity of sand in the bottom of the well and the resultant stoppage of the pump when it was installed on March 3rd.

Signed by.....F. Rhodes.
Principal.
E. S. Jones, Esq.
Actg. Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I wish to confirm the wire sent to the Department by Mr. M. Christiansen, General Sup't. of Indian Agencies, reporting the fire at the File Hills Indian Residential School. This fire, which was discovered at 7.45 P.M. April 8th, 1942, totally destroyed the two class rooms and contents.

The class rooms, situated 35 feet from the main building were of lumber structure, 100 feet by 28 feet, with full sized basement. One half of the basement was of cement structure, the other half stone.

This building was heated by a pipeless furnace. The chimney was of brick construction built from the basement.

The class rooms were built at different periods. The actual date of the first structure is not available, the addition was built in 1924.

The contents of the building comprised:

90 Pupils Desks
2 Teachers Desks,

Dear Sir:

Further to my wire of the 9th instant advising you that the classrooms and contents at the File Hills Indian Residential School, Balcarres, had been destroyed by fire, I wish to inform you that Mr. Jones, the Agent, and the Reverend Mr. Huston, are in my office this morning.

We have decided upon the following. If the Branch will authorize $100.00 for the purpose of buying lumber, nails, etc. and hiring a carpenter, Mr. Jones has undertaken to build benches and tables to be placed in the two playrooms so that school can be carried on at the present time. We even may not require quite the $100.00 and Mr. Jones thinks he will be able to fix up the two playrooms so that they are suitable.

Mr. Jones and Mr. Huston brought in a list of school materials required but in discussing this with me we came to the conclusion that since there was some school material on hand we could manage for the present. As I pointed out to them, nothing should be ordered at present, only sufficient to carry on school until the end of the school term. This will give the Branch breathing space to decide what to do before school re-opens in the Fall.

The Agent is taking the lists for the school material back to Balcarres and Mr. Huston is going up to the School on Tuesday. He will remain there for two or three days and the material on hand will be thoroughly checked. Only materials actually required will be asked for.

I am sending this letter by Air Mail and you will receive it on Monday morning. Will you please wire me the necessary authority to proceed with this work. If I do not hear from you by noon on Monday I will take it for granted that I have authority for Mr. Jones to take the necessary steps to purchase the material and get the work underway.

Loss $10,000
In Indian School Fire

Fire destroyed the building in which classes were held for about 250 children of File Hills Indian residential school, Thursday morning, according to information for agent E. S. Jones to M. Christianson, inspector of Indian agencies in Alberta. The loss is approximately $10,000. This building, a frame structure on cement foundations, with two large classrooms, and a hall between, was erected about three years ago.

There will be a problem for the present to find land where classes may be held, pending the announcement from the government as to whether a new building will be constructed or not.

By prompt action on part of volunteers, the main building housing a large number of Indian children was saved.
AIR MAIL

Regina, Saskatchewan
April 17th, 1942

Dear Sir:

Regarding the burning of the classrooms at the File Hills Indian Residential School, which happened on the 8th instant, when Mr. Jones, the Indian Agent, was in the office here last week he was of the opinion that the fire had been started by faulty electric wiring. However, he now informs me that a few days after some of the children started to discuss the fire at different times and there were a lot of rumours floating around. Therefore Mr. Jones got in touch with Cpl. McCarro, of the R.C.M.Police, Balcarres, who carried out an investigation at the school, during which three boys admitted setting fire to the school.

The boy who actually lit the match and started the fire is only 12 years old and is from the Carlton Agency, Mistawasis Reserve. Benny Pasqua and Jimmy Keepiness, aged 15, of the Qu'Appelle Agency, helped the little fellow and more or less forced him to start the fire.

Agent Jones was in the office today and we went to see Superintendent Darling, of the R.C.M. Police here in the city. While we were there he got in touch with Commissioner Ring, of the Bureau of Child Protection and it was decided to take the three boys into custody. Mr. Jones is to lay the charges tonight when he returns to Balcarres. These boys will be brought in to Regina very likely tomorrow and placed in the Industrial School here until such time as their case comes up.

Have you any instructions to give in the matter? You will receive this letter on Monday morning, as I am sending it by Air Mail, and if you write back immediately I should receive your reply on Tuesday. The Police Report will not be forwarded by Cpl. McCarro until about Monday.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Further to my letter of even date regarding the fire at the File Hills School, the Indian Agent informs me that the staff there have all more or less become panic stricken since it was learnt that the boys started the fire. Mr. Jones also further informs me that although the three boys I mentioned in my letter have admitted their guilt I think that the bigger boys are all more or less implicated.

Personally I think it was a mistake to leave Miss Pugh in charge. She may be a "fine old girl" but certainly not capable of handling a lot of big boys and girls. However, this is not the purpose of this letter. The Agent claims there are three boys there who are 16 years of age and they should be discharged immediately before they do something that they shouldn't, as there is no one there to handle them. The boys are Arnold Peshawisis from the Mistawasis Reserve, Wilfred Haywanhi from the Carry the Kettle Reserve, and Stanley Pasqua, of the Pasqua Reserve, Qu'Appelle Agency, and as the term has only approximately two months more to run I think probably it would be a good idea to act on Mr. Jones' recommendation.

Mr. Jones wishes to have the fireman, whose term at the school expires at the end of April, kept on for another month and I agreed to this. However, if you think otherwise let me know.

In conclusion I am of the opinion the Branch should get after the United Church and insist on another Principal being appointed. A man living at Round Lake cannot look after that school as well as someone living at File Hills. At present the male staff at the File Hills School are "weak sisters" and Mr. Jones feels that the boys fully intended to burn down the main building as well as the classrooms.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

You will recall that both the 1942 and 1943 Estimates included a set of batteries for the Delco lighting plant of our School. This, however, was not granted, but instead, a sum was authorized for the purchase of one cell to replace one which exploded and also for the overhaul of four other cells which had become clogged with sediment. As a result of these repairs we were able to carry on through the winter months. Gradually during the past two months the service has become poorer and poorer until it is necessary to keep the motor running continually in order to obtain satisfactory service. The batteries will not store up sufficient energy to operate the radio; immediately the motor is shut off the radio goes dead and the lights in the building become dim. Several mornings there was not enough "juice" in the batteries to start the motor, and it became necessary to start the laundry engine and run the auxiliary generator before the motor could be started. It is quite evident that this set of batteries is exhausted and should be replaced immediately.

Would you kindly bring this matter to the attention of the Department, urging that immediate action be taken in the purchase of a complete new set of heavy duty batteries.

Yours Truly,

L. L. Dobbin, Principal

Dear Sirs:

Our heating engineer Mr. P. Hill, of Fort Qu'Appelle has made an examination of the Gurney boiler at The File Hills Residential School and found that the boiler was in very poor condition.

He found that the tubes were completely plugged with an alkali or an iron deposit that is almost impossible to remove. This would make it necessary to renew all the tubes in the boiler and possibly retap the openings. The feasibility of this can only be ascertained after the boiler is dismantled. If this could be done the cost would be upwards of $300.00.

He recommends that it would be far better to install a new boiler, a water softener, and a smaller jacket heater. The cost of the boiler is not known at the present time, nor is that of a water softener. A suitable jacket heater could possibly be installed for about $75.00 to $100.00. This installation would eliminate the using of the larger boilers during the warm period of the year when steam pressure is not necessary for heating purposes.

Yours truly,

Sgd. J. E. Chaplin
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I, however, got in touch with the boiler inspector who inspects several of our schools and he advised me what they were doing in connection with several of the apartments here in town. They have been installing tractor boilers instead of the regular heating plants and this is working out very satisfactorily, therefore I passed this information along to Mr. Mills and also gave him the name of the man who is doing this work around Regina. I further gave him this man's quotation which was $450.00 for the Round Lake School and $650.00 for the File Hills School.
