Re: Heating system, File Hills Residential School,
Balcarres, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your memoranda of August 20th and October 7th, relative to the above, this matter was referred immediately on receipt of your first memorandum to our Engineering and Construction Service who at that time had the heating system at the Round Lake Indian Residential School under consideration. As it had not proved possible to arrange for an inspection at the Round Lake School satisfactory from all points of view, the inspection at the File Hills School was left in abeyance as your memorandum of August 26th did not lead us to consider the situation at the latter school particularly urgent and we were not prepared to make a recommendation on information which Mr. Christianson was able to secure and which he furnished on September 11th.

In this connection there would seem to be some confusion as to dates in Mr. Christianson's letter of October 4th, of which you sent us a copy.

Also in this connection we would suggest that Indian Agents be advised, particularly in view both of our shortness of staff for all projects that have to be taken care of, the general labour situation and the most inevitable lack delay before new equipment of any kind can be secured, that where they suspect any heating equipment not to be in good order that they ask for its inspection in April or May rather than in August.

Our Engineering and Construction Service has been in communication with the Deputy Minister of Public Works for Saskatchewan asking his co-operation in obtaining a report on the existing installation at the File Hills School. A report has just been received prepared by Mr. H. W. Mayhew, Chief Inspector of Steam Boilers for the Saskatchewan Department of Public Works, of which a copy is attached for your information.

You will observe that the school is now being supplied with steam for heating and laundering, from two low pressure boilers of uncertain age, and that the smaller of these is described as a complete wreck. Mr. Mayhew further states that it is possible the larger boiler may have to be replaced in the near future, but in the absence of any criticism of this unit, it is assumed that satisfactory service can be provided at least for the present by replacing the smaller boiler.

In this connection Mr. Mayhew has ascertained that a Sufford cast iron sectional boiler, #536-6, manufactured by the Dominion Radiator Company Ltd., in good condition and having a larger capacity than the boiler it would replace is available at the Balcarres Hotel for a cost of $125.00. How this boiler became available is not stated, but on checking by our Engineering and Construction Service it would appear to be a six-section unit, manufactured in 1935 or 1936, and, as reported by Mr. Mayhew, would cost approximately $1000.00 if new. The boiler is capable of assuming approximately 45% of the school load, whereas the boiler it replaces carries just over 40%.
EX'D.

October 14, 1943.

Memorandum

Mr. C.W. Jackson

Indian Affairs Branch recommend the purchase of a used Safford Cast Iron, sectional boiler 7S-36-d, to replace the present boiler at the File Hills Indian Residential School at Balcarres, Sask. The boiler is obtainable from the Balcarres Hotel at a cost of $125.00. A new boiler of the same type would cost approximately $1000.00.

The boiler at the Balcarres Hotel has been inspected by a provincial boiler inspector, who reports that it is suitable, in good condition, and free from scale. Engineering and Surveys Branch consider that Mr. Christianson should be authorized to make the purchase and to engage to obtain the services of a reliable contractor to install it. Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to acknowledge the Department's letter No. 111-1-5 of October 15th together with a letter from Mr. C.W. Jackson, the Chief Executive Assistant, in connection with the furnace at the File Hills School.

I was down at the File Hills Agency yesterday and the day before, and I visited the school. Everything in connection with the furnace appeared to be in first class shape and it was giving fine heat. The whole thing amounted to $333.36 and I would recommend the two vouchers for payment.

I just want to say here that the other furnace probably will go out of commission in a very short time because it probably is all corroded but it is to be hoped that it will last throughout the Winter. If the weather is not too cold the furnace we shipped in will probably heat the school. However, if it gets real cold it would not do it. Therefore if we have an opportunity to buy another furnace the way we did this one I think we should take advantage of it and I can get the Provincial boiler inspectors to help me in this matter if you wish.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: File Hills Residential School

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of June 24th authorizing the inclusion of an amount of $7,000 in the Supplementary Estimates in order to construct a new classroom building at the above mentioned residential school. The necessary instructions in this regard are being given to the Representative of the Treasury.

In order that authority may be given for immediate construction of this building, it would be appreciated if the Minister would approve our using, for the present, the amount of $5,000 provided in the current year's Main Appropriation for the Cross Lake United Church School. This amount cannot be spent during the current fiscal year.

If this were done, the amount of $7,000 provided in the Supplementary Estimates would be available before the building was completed, which would enable us to pay the extra $2,000 and leave the Main Appropriation as it is today.

Attention of Mr. Hoey.

I wish to inform you that I was down at the File Hills School yesterday and while there Mr. Dobbin, the Principal, informed me he had been asked by the United Church to supply plans for two new classrooms and he was getting the cost of building because he understands that the Church is going to submit this to the Department.

I had a little talk with him about this because I know just how matters are at the school at the present time, and here in a nutshell is what is going on there. As you know, the teaching has been carried on in the two playrooms and it is necessary every morning and night to move some of the furnishings in these rooms. Mr. Dobbin had two good teachers there but both have resigned and have no intention of coming back. Mr. Dobbin pointed out he does not know where he is going to get teachers and I quite realize that nobody who knew what the conditions for teaching are like there would accept a position of teacher there. I was there last Winter and I felt sorry for the two lady teachers who were teaching under such a terrible handicap. Personally I think Mr. Dobbin is getting along fairly well and both he and his wife are very fine people. I think they have the confidence of the Indians because they have instilled kindness into the school amongst the children and military tactics have been done away with. Still at the same time I know Mr. Dobbin can be firm with the children. While conditions remain as they are at present the children cannot possibly get the education they should receive. For example under one of the playrooms an engine is continually running and you can understand that this is distracting to whatever teacher they might have. The teachers resigning this year is just a sample of what will happen in the future because, as I have already stated, no teacher will remain long so long as existing circumstances remain. I know there is a war on and our Branch find it hard to get money but I sincerely hope that when the United Church present their request it will receive every consideration.

My reason for writing.....

Attention of Mr. Phelan,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 111-1-5 of the 7th instant in connection with the request from the Principal of the File Hills Residential School.

In reply I wish to state I was out at the school the day before yesterday and yesterday, and Mr. Simpson and I went into the matter of repairs, etc. with the Principal.

I am attaching a requisition in duplicate for repairs amounting to $150.84. This is all required and some of the work to be done there can only be done by skilled labour. However, anything that can be handled by the staff will be performed by them and Mr. Dobbin stated he would have all of the work he could done by the staff, therefore $22.00 can be taken off this amount, leaving the total at $128.84.

I am also enclosing a requisition in duplicate signed by Mr. Simpson for the material for the pig pen and this is required. We could make the building a little smaller if it is absolutely necessary but I think for future use at the school they require the building as outlined and this will cost $695.78. The price is from the North American Supply Company with head office in Winnipeg. I was down to see the manager of the Yards in Balcarres and he informed me the price he had quoted was the one he gave to everyone but the Purchasing Agent may be able to do better.

The school also need a jacket heater which the hardware man in Balcarres quoted at $100.00. This is required to heat water. If you can get lower prices on the lumber the total cost might be brought down to the amount mentioned in your letter, namely $750.00 but in any event the things I have mentioned should be supplied because they are necessary and I am sure Mr. Dobbin will do his best to keep the amount within what will be allowed.

I further explained to Mr. Dobbin...
I further explained to Mr. Dobbin that the seeder would not be supplied, also the washer in the amount of $575.00. This was requested because the washer now in use at the school is really too small but I told Mr. Dobbin he would have to try to get along as best he could for the present.

I think he can do without the 8 spools of wire for fencing and the posts totalling $66.00 for the present time. Also, there has been lots of rain around File Hills at the present time and I do not believe the dug-out is absolutely necessary just now. However, as I have said before, I trust that the amounts which are necessary will be supplied.

M. Christianson,

My dear Colleague:

Attached is copy of a letter which I have received from Dr. George Dorey, Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada.

I may say that there has been a very important mission of the United Church on the File Hills Indian Reserve for many years. I think it is one of the Reserves that the United Church has taken a great deal of interest in and has been very proud of. Mrs. Motherwell for many years was closely associated with it, and still takes a great interest in the work which is being done there. I think it would be most unfortunate if the school was not continued at its past high standard, and am very anxious to see the building proceeded with at an early date as possible.

You will recall that the Indian school at Lebret was burned some years ago. It was during the period that the Bennett Government were in office. They almost immediately proceeded with the reconstruction of a new building of a very much better type and at a much higher cost than the old one. As these two schools are close enough together to be known by all the people in the community there are some comparisons being made which are not helpful.

I am sure it will be the intention of the Department to rebuild this school, and I hope they can have it completed before the coming winter.

Yours sincerely,

sgd) James G. Gardiner.

I have a letter from our Indian Agent at File Hills, Mr. S.H. Simpson, with respect to the water supply at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

At one time there was a small lake near the school and the water was pumped therefrom for use but this year the water has dried up considerably and it is not deep enough for school purposes, and is now only used by the cattle. Mr. Dobbin is therefore requesting that a dug-out be constructed 165 ft. long; 60 ft. wide; and 12 ft. deep to cost $125.00. A suitable site is available near the school.

I would recommend that this matter be given consideration and if money could be found available as it is necessary to have a supply of water at the school. Arrangements will be made to have this work completed early this Fall.

Mr. S.H. Simpson, Indian Agent, Balcarres, Sask.

The Department is interested in knowing what progress is being made with the erection of the new classroom building at the File Hills Residential School. An early report on this building would be appreciated.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Departmental letter 111-1-5, Sept., 29th., pertaining to the new classroom building now under construction at the File Hills Residential School, I beg to report as follows:

The cement basement is completed, excepting half of the cement floor.

All outside work of the building is completed, excepting the siding on one end and both sides, and painting of the walls and roof.

Inside work; The first flooring has been laid. The walls are sheated and insulated, and the ceiling is half sheated, and insulated. The walls and ceiling have also to be plastered.

The chimney is now under construction.

Procuring of building materials has been the chief cause of delay in this work. Procuring of labour has also been more or less a problem.

Mr. Dobbin, Principal of the school has informed me that he was able to procure the balance of the siding required, and the flooring, yesterday, and expects to be able to procure the balance of the sheathing for the ceiling, also that he does not anticipate any further delay in this work through being unable to procure the necessary building materials.

Mr. Hasty, building contractor advised me that providing there was no holdup in procuring labour, or materials, he expected to have this work completed within the next month.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Regina, October 13th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that some time ago the Indian Agent at File Hills, Mr. S.H. Simpson, discussed with me the matter of getting some fire fighting apparatus for the Agency to protect the school, Agency buildings, and other buildings in the Agency. This, of course, was a while ago when we thought that a lot of equipment was going to be turned over to us after the war.

However, I asked Mr. Simpson to make up a requisition for what was necessary and he has just forwarded this to me. I am now attaching this in duplicate. If any equipment of this nature is available I thought probably it would be well to supply this to the File Hills Agency. However, there are probably men employed with our Branch in Ottawa who know more about fire fighting equipment than I do because I must admit I know very little.

In any event I am forwarding the requisition for your attention, as previously stated.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
October 17, 1944.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I am sending forward herewith a requisition for certain supplies that appear to be needed for fire protection at the File Hills School and File Hills Agency buildings. I am sending forward also copy of the letter from Mr. Christianson that accompanied this requisition. It is my understanding that this requisition is based, in part at least, on the assumption that a certain amount of this equipment will be available from military sources.

In view of our desire to do everything humanly possible to protect our buildings from fire, we would be prepared to purchase this equipment new if the total cost is at all reasonable. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would let us know by phone what the approximate cost might be.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Report on File Hills Indian Residential School

I might say while at the Agency I visited the File Hills Indian Residential School and everything there seemed to be going along fairly satisfactory.

The staff there were glad to know that the classrooms are being rebuilt. I was in the new classrooms talking to the man in charge, Mr. Dick Hasty, whom I have known for the past thirty years. He is getting up in years but he is a first class carpenter and we can depend on anything Mr. Hasty does therefore I know he will make a good job of rebuilding these classrooms. Mr. Hasty told me that they probably would be finished at the end of this month but on account of the shortage of labour he thought it might take him a couple of weeks longer so in all probability it will be on in November some time before the building is completed. However, it is closed in and there should be no trouble in finishing even if the weather does get cold.

The Principal again brought to my attention the boiler at the school. When Mr. Mayhow, Provincial Boiler Inspector, was down there last he reported to me when the new boiler was being installed that we should make arrangements to purchase another new boiler to replace the other one, and I brought this to the attention of our Branch. I again brought this to the attention of our Branch on July 17th last since no action had been taken stating that the boiler was not satisfactory but again no attention was paid to this by our Branch. To quote Mr. Dobbin's remarks it does not matter how much you fire this boiler it is so badly caked that very little results are obtained from the fuel burned in this heating plant therefore they are depending mostly on the boiler that was installed a year ago last Fall at the school and in real cold weather this is not sufficient. The matter of having a new boiler installed should be given consideration.

The staff at the school, of course, is new as several of the ladies there are beginning their first year but there were one or two ladies who were there before I certainly was not sorry to see leave this institution. Mr. Dobbin, the Principal, seems to be carrying on very satisfactorily.

Mr. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Electrical installation of File Hills Reserve, at Balcarres, Residential School, was inspected on the (X) 19th day of September 1944.

DEFECTS:

No main entrance or central switch ahead of panel.
B.K. used for sub-entrance into laundry.
Wall switch outlets defective.
Flexible cords used to extend circuits from panel.

The above does not conform to the requirements of the Canadian Electrical Code and constitutes a danger or a potential danger to life or property. The following changes must be made within 30 days from the date hereof:

For use with 32 volt system: Properly install sub-service into laundry to Canadian Electrical Code requirements. Remove all flexible cord wiring tapped to circuit wires at panel. Repair or renew defective wall outlets and switch devices.

For use with 110 volt system: Install service and 60 amp. externally operated fused switch ahead of panel distribution, and entrance to Code standard if isolated plant is located outside of main building. Also carry out repairs as required for general safety, see re 32 volt above.

Failure to have the defects remedied within the time specified may result in discontinuance of service to the premises.

Dated at Regina, this 19th day of September 1944.

Act. Chief Inspector,

In spite of several communications, we have been unable to obtain a proper accounting for the advance that was made and, as a consequence, we are unable to make any further payments.

I enclose, for your information, a copy of a letter sent to the Principal yesterday. This letter outlines the situation existing at the present time.

I would appreciate it if you would get in touch with the Principal immediately and assist him in preparing a proper credit voucher for the advance already forwarded and also prepare and forward the accounts for the additional $2,000.00. The funds for the erection of this building were provided in the current year's appropriation, and consequently it is absolutely essential that we have all the accounts in proper form at the earliest possible date, as the end of the current fiscal year is rapidly approaching.

Encl.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

MR. VINCENT.

With reference to your telephone enquiry regarding our requisition of March 1, for a boiler for the File Hills School, the following is a quotation from a report received from the Surveys & Engineering Branch on October 12, 1943, in connection with the heating system of this school:

"You will observe that the school is now being supplied with steam for heating and laundering, from two low pressure boilers of uncertain age, and that the smaller of these is described as a complete wreck. Mr. Mayhew further states that it is possible the larger boiler may have to be replaced in the near future, but in the absence of any criticism of this unit, it is assumed that satisfactory service can be provided at least for the present by replacing the smaller boiler."

Mr. Mayhew, mentioned above, is the Chief Inspector of Steam Boilers for the Saskatchewan Department of Public Works.

Following receipt of this report, we purchased a second hand boiler at a cost of $600.00. Authority for this purchase was contained in your memorandum of October 15, 1943 - your File No. 15-3 S.

In a letter dated July 17, 1944, Mr. Christianson, former General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, advised us that the larger boiler mentioned in the extract quoted above was badly coated with scale and would have to be replaced. In reply, we asked him to

p.t.o.
let us know if a second hand boiler could be secured and, if so, at what cost and from whom. We did not receive any reply to that communication until we received the letters attached to our requisition of March 1, 1945.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Would you kindly draw the attention of the Department to the following urgent matters pertaining to our School, with a view to having action taken in regard to them.

For a considerable number of years past, the water for laundry and other purposes has been heated in a tank placed in a horizontal position above and to one side of the boilers. Inside this tank is a copper coil through live steam from the boiler is forced, thus heating the water in the tank. This was quite satisfactory in winter, but during the summer months it was necessary to keep a fire in one of the boilers continually in order to have sufficient hot water available. More fuel was consumed than necessary, and the building was kept too warm. At the present time the tank is leaking in several places and will have to be replaced very soon. We would suggest that it be replaced with a jacket heater of sufficient capacity for our needs. We believe that it would be more economical and efficient than the present arrangement.

The other matter for consideration is the painting of the new classroom building. The funds provided by the Department for its construction were not sufficient to cover exterior painting, and in order to prevent deterioration of the siding this should be done at once. The dimensions of the building are 40'x52' with a 12' side wall.

Your early attention to these matters will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Regina, April 26th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

When visiting at the File Hills Residential School last week my attention was directed to the condition of the tank used for heating the water for washing purposes. This tank was leaking in two places and temporarily patched. I expect that at a very early date it will go to pieces entirely. I asked Mr. Dobbin, the Principal, to write me regarding this and I am enclosing his letter.

You will note that he requests a jacket heater instead of replacing the hot water tank. It is very uneconomical to make a large fire in one of the boilers in order to heat water for washing purposes in the summer, and that is what is required with the present arrangement. The wisdom in substituting a jacket heater is obvious.

Mention is made in Mr. Dobbin's letter of the need for painting the new classroom building. I understand that the funds allowed for the erection of the building did not allow sufficient for painting. In Mr. Dobbin's letter he does not mention the cost of this but he informed me in conversation that he had received an estimate of $75.00 for material and labour for a two-coat job. I doubt that this is sufficient and I find that most of the estimates given Mr. Dobbin by local experts have been far too low. I instructed Mr. Dobbin to make provision in his next Estimates for these two matters but I am bringing them to your attention now because I am afraid that at any time a replacement of the water heating plant will be urgently needed.

Mr. Dobbin showed me some accounts which he had just received for a rather large expenditure in connection with repairs to the water works and sewage at the school, and showed me where the repairs had been made. No authority for the expenditure had been received from the Department and I believe no request was made for authority by the school but the work was done when urgently needed.

I explained to Mr. Dobbin the need for anticipating repair expenditure. For instance it is very obvious that in view of the fact that many of the pipes are now so badly corroded that......
are now so badly corroded that they are nearly completely filled, and others are so badly rusted that they are starting to leak, a rather large expenditure in this connection will be necessary very soon, and I instructed him to place all these matters in the next Estimates, after having had quotations giving an estimate of the probable cost. From my own observations I feel that a great deal of trouble is coming at a not far distant date in connection with the sewage system at this school and it may be necessary to do considerable replacement of pipes.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, May 5, 1945.

With reference to your letter #306-11A of May 9th, pertaining to a jacket heater for the File Hills Residential School, I beg to report as follows:

The hot water tank at the school is leaking badly. It is also badly corroded and cannot be repaired to make it serviceable for the purpose for which it is required. The hot water supply for the school is provided through the furnace heating coils placed within this tank. These coils are also badly corroded. Apart from that this system of heating water is not suitable or satisfactory, as when a supply of hot water is required a furnace fire has to be put on. This results in heating the whole of the school building. It is also an expensive of procuring hot water during the months that the building does not require to be heated.

Form 37 in triplicate is attached hereto listing the equipment essential to provide sufficient hot water for the requirements of the school. Prices stated were quoted by J.E. Chaplin, Hardware Merchant, Balsamroot, Sask. Cost of labour installing equipment is to be taken care of by the school.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Simpson:

I enclose herewith 4 invoices (in triplicate) as follows:

1. Dated Jan. 29th 1945 - J.E.Chaplin - $28.55
2. Dated Feb. 2nd 1945 - J.E.Chaplin - $104.84
3. Dated Mar. 22nd 1945 - J.H.Ashdown Hardware Co. - $55.55
4. Dated Mar. 26th 1945 - J.E.Chaplin - $55.25

Each of the above are for emergency material or labor for repairs to the Sewage Disposal and Water System at the School.

Invoice No. 1 - This expenditure was incurred after the drain from the kitchen sink refused to function. Every effort was made to clear the drain, without any success, and it was decided to abandon the old drain, which ran underneath the cement floor, and install another above the floor. It was necessary to do this at once.

Invoice No. 2 - This expenditure was for replacement and installation of a new pressure tank for drinking water, the old one having sprung a leak in a number of places through rusting. The walls and bottom of the tank had become so thin that it was useless to try to repair it. A new one had to be purchased at once in order to provide drinking water for the pupils.

Invoice No. 3 - This was for the purchase of a new rotary pump. The main sewer which leads to the disposal tank became clogged, resisting all efforts to dislodge the obstruction. The trouble occurred between the second and third manholes and caused the sewage to back up into the basement of the School. The only possible way to relieve this condition was to pump the sewage from the second manhole and convey it through a pipe above ground and allow it to empty into the third manhole. This necessitated the purchase of a new pump, and like the previous situations, had to be remedied immediately.

Invoice No. 4 - This was for the purchase of new pipes and rods for the deep well from which we obtain practically our entire water supply for the School during the winter months. It became necessary to make some repairs to the cylinder of the pump and to do this the pipes and rods had to be raised to the surface. On close examination it was discovered that many of the pipes were perforated with holes due to rust. The rods were also in a very bad state due to the same cause and it would have been very unwise to continue to use them. It therefore became imperative that we purchase new pipes and rods throughout.

Would you kindly bring these matters to the attention of the Department, with a view to having the expenditures met from...
emergency funds.

Yours very truly,

L. L. Dobbin
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith Voucher No. 23 for $183.64 in favour of J.E. Chaplin of Balcarres, and Voucher No. 24 for $33.55 in favour of the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company Limited, Regina, for necessary repairs at the File Hills Indian Residential School. Also enclosed is a letter from Mr. L.L. Dobbin, Principal of the school, which outlines the need for the repairs in question.

When I visited this school on the 19th ultimo I inspected the repairs referred to and have no hesitation in saying that they were badly needed.

Some reference was made to this matter in my letter of the 26th ultimo reporting on my visit to that school, and while I realize that large expenditures of this kind should be anticipated wherever possible, and so instructed Mr. Dobbin, I would recommend that the vouchers enclosed be paid.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

I attach account amounting to $183.64, covering the cost of emergency purchases and repairs at the File Hills Indian Residential School. The Principal supplies the following information with reference to these expenditures:

"Each of the above are for emergency material or labour for repairs to the sewage disposal and water system at the school.

"Invoice No. 1 - This expenditure was incurred after the drain from the kitchen sink refused to function. Every effort was made to clear the drain, without any success, and it was decided to abandon the old drain, which ran underneath the cement floor, and install another above the floor. It was necessary to do this at once.

"Invoice No. 2 - This expenditure was for replacement and installation of a new pressure tank for drinking water, the old one having sprung a leak in a number of places through rusting. The walls and bottom of the tank had become so thin that it was useless to try to repair it. A new one had to be purchased at once, in order to provide drinking water for the pupils.

"Invoice No. 3 - This was for the purchase of a new rotary pump. The main sewer which leads to the disposal tank became clogged, resisting all efforts to dislodge the obstruction. The trouble occurred..."
between the second and third manholes and caused the sewage to back up into the basement of the school. The only possible way to relieve this condition was to pump the sewage from the second manhole and convey it through a pipe above ground and allow it to empty into the third manhole. This necessitated the purchase of a new pump and, like the previous situation, had to be remedied immediately."

It would be appreciated if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid.

The coding is as follows: 76 - 653 - 10-691.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will remember that a year ago you authorized the expenditure of $7,000 to rebuild the School at File Hills. I am advised by Mr. Dobbin that he has actually expended $7,475.49. I wonder whether it would be possible for the Department to increase the grant to that extent. My personal opinion is that an increase of $470.00 over the estimate, in view of the fact that prices have been very unstable, is not a bad record. The largest amount of the increase is in the furnace. Mr. Dobbin was not able to purchase the type of furnace he had hoped to get. Because of wartime restrictions, he had to purchase what he could get. That made it more expensive.

We shall be glad if you will give the matter consideration.

With reference to your letter #306-11A enclosing the original and duplicate copy of unnumbered voucher for $282.41 in favour of J.E. Chaplin pertaining to the installation of a boiler and jacket heater at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

Mr. Chaplin advises that the reason the cost in installing the boiler appears to be high is due to having to dismantle and remove the old boiler, breaking up and removing the cement foundation thereunder, and constructing a new cement foundation for the new boiler which had to be replastered and insulated, as the old plaster and insulation had been broken off, probably in transit from Regina by truck. This work had to be done in addition to connecting the new boiler to the pipe system already installed. He claims that the hours employed in installing the heater and connecting the tank are normal.

Further detail has been given on the two receipts, amounting to $84.00 and $15.00 respectively. Mr. Dobbin, Principal of the School, has certified as to the receipt of goods, and labour listed on the invoices submitted by Mr. Chaplin.

The voucher made out by this office is not numbered as it is not entered in our office voucher record, due to authority of the purchase of the new boiler and jacket heater, and the labour in connection being arranged by Ottawa through your office, which would want to voucher and record the accounts pertaining thereto.

Enclosed herewith are the documents referred to herein.

With reference to your letter 306-11A of Sept. 10th, pertaining to the prices quoted on screen doors and window blinds listed on Form 37 of Aug. 24th, I beg to advise that the prices listed thereon are estimated.

The North American Lumber Co. at Balcarres, have more orders for screen doors and windows than they can fill and do not care to quote a price thereon as they are not in a position to fill our requirements if an order was placed with them.

Mr. Dobbin, Principal of the school, stated that he understood venetian blinds were being supplied for classrooms, as they have been found more suitable for classroom work, and outlast the common cloth type. The price stated on the requisition form is an estimate of the cost of the venetian type. At the time the requisition was submitted Mr. Chaplin, local hardware merchant, was absent in Winnipeg, and his price on venetian blinds could not be procured.

It is recommended that the screens and blinds be procured in Regina or some large centre, as delivery from local source is uncertain at present, and the local cost would undoubtedly be much higher.

A letter was forwarded to the Department from this office on January 12th, 1945, file No. 306-4A, enclosing a report of an electrical inspection by provincial authorities of the electric wiring at the File Hills Indian Residential School and the File Hills Agency.

I have not a copy of this inspection report but apparently a considerable quantity of equipment was condemned.

There has been some correspondence between this office and the Department in connection with the whole question of the lighting plant at the File Hills Residential School and the File Hills Agency but nothing has been done.

The Provincial Government authorities are now requesting a report on the progress in connection with the bringing of the electrical installations at that point up to standard.

If no action is to be taken in connection with a complete change of the lighting plant at the File Hills Agency at the present time would it be in order to make an effort to secure the necessary wire and insulators to meet the requirements of the provincial authorities at an early date?

J.P.R. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of June 28th, 1944, No. 111-1-5, advising that a requisition was being forwarded to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for material for a pig pen at the File Hills Indian Residential School, amounting to $473.85, the Principal of the School is now asking for authority to submit a voucher in connection with the cost of the labour in constructing this building, no authority for the labour having been given him at the time.

The Principal, Mr. Dobbin, states that the cost of the labour was $233.25 and because of lack of funds he has been unable to pay the whole of this and still owes $178.50 thereon. He states further that when he received authority for the expenditure of $7,000.00 last year for the construction of the new classroom building he had to use $538.94 of the funds of the school, being the difference between the amount allowed and the total cost.

In view of the heavy expenditure from school funds in order to complete these buildings Mr. Dobbin is now asking for authority to submit a voucher for $178.50 to pay the amount still owing in connection with the labour of constructing the pig pen. I would be glad to have authority granted for this and would ask that Mr. Simpson, the Indian Agent, be so advised at an early date.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

J.P.B. Ostrander Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Re- Your office letters No.306-11A of Aug.11/44,
and 306-4A of April 21st. 1945.
Dugout for File Hills Residential School.

No E.R. certificate has been received by this office in connection with the enclosed voucher No.198 - $125.00.

As the dugout machinery completed the dugout at Agency Headquarters on Oct. 15th, I had the one at the school done, as the water situation there is not good, and it was questionable that a machine could be procured before 1947 due to the work it had contracted to do in 1945 and 1946.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith voucher No. 198 in favour of the Rural Municipality of Tullymet, No. 216, Balcarres, in the amount of $125.00, for the construction of a dug-out at the File Hills Indian Residential School. Also enclosed is copy of a letter received from Mr. S.H. Simpson, the Indian Agent, explaining the reason for proceeding with this work before authority had been actually received.

I may say in this connection that my letter of April 21st, 1945, to which Mr. Simpson refers, was to advise Mr. Simpson of the contents of Department letter of April 16th, 1945, No. 21-111, by which I was given authority to proceed with the construction of the dug-out at the Agency, and advising him that he should expect authority for the dug-out at the school in another letter.

I received no further instructions from the Department with regard to the school dug-out and Mr. Simpson did not again bring the matter to my attention.

The dug-out at the school is badly needed and its cost was considerably reduced by the fact that the machinery was close to the school making the Indian Agency dug-out. I would therefore recommend that the voucher be paid.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

I am enclosing herewith requisition and letter of Indian Agent Simpson from the File Hills Agency in connection with material and labour for exterior painting of the Department buildings at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

The buildings in question are all very badly in need of paint and I would recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure if funds are now available.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, July 15, 1946.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

I have your letter (No. 1069-306-LLA) of the 3rd instant, with reference to painting at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

The Department approves the acceptance of the tender of $256.00 for material and labour for painting the main building.

If we supplied the paint required for the other buildings, would it not be possible to have these buildings painted in the Fall, by the larger boys?

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 15th instant, No. 111-1-5 W T 1, in connection with painting of the buildings of the File Hills Indian Residential School.

Regarding the third paragraph of your letter the building is very high and we would have to purchase special equipment for the painting.

While I am certainly in favour of having the larger boys perform duties which would mean something to them in their training I do not know that I would recommend work of this kind. The scaffolding will be high and even if it is well constructed it would not be constructed entirely safe against the possibility of the boys doing some thoughtless act which might result in a serious fall or injury in some other manner. There is so much criticism by the Indians whenever their boys are asked to perform useful work about the school that I think it is wise to confine their work to work which is at least quite safe.

We have always avoided having the Indian boys perform any work which might be dangerous and I would recommend that this policy be continued at least during the period in the immediate future and while the question of the management of Indian residential schools is being considered by the Parliamentary Committee.

I would be in favour of having the boys perform some of the labour of painting where they can stand on the ground or not very high on scaffolding but there are many buildings at the File Hills Residential School which are quite high, requiring a considerable amount of scaffolding.

Please instruct me further in this connection.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Ottawa, August 1, 1946.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

I have your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to painting buildings at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

The Department agrees with you that the Indian boys should not be requested to do work where there is any danger of serious injury.

In official letter of July 15th, we authorized the expenditure of $256.00 for material and labour for painting the main building. You may authorize an additional $250.00 and the Agent and Principal can decide the buildings that can be painted this year with the amount authorized.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Please advise me whether it is intended to authorize the whole amount at $683.50 for the main building plus $250.00 to be distributed over other necessary exterior painting.

J.F.B. Ostrander,

J.P.B.Ostrander Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Attached hereto is Form 37 listing materials and labour required to install wash basins for use of the pupils at the File Hills Residential School.

All wash basins for use of the pupils are located in the sleeping dormitories on the top floor of the building. Before meals and at other times during the day when use has to be made of these basins, the children have to climb one or two flights of stairs accompanied by their supervisor. It is not always possible for the supervisor to accompany them and at such times the children make play rooms of the dormitories, with consequent damage to furniture, bedding etc. In order that the dormitories may be kept closed during the day, and to avoid unnecessary tramping of dirt along corridors, up two flights of stairs and throughout the dormitories it is recommended that seven of the fourteen basins now in each of the dormitories be removed and installed downstairs.

Form 27 is enclosed herewith pertaining to the following necessary items.

1. The main stringers which support the large main entrance steps to the main school building have rotted and at present are supported by being propped up with pieces of 2" x 6" plank, which is considered very unsafe. The flooring of the veranda of the main building is badly worn and is not safe in places.

2. The room occupied by the boy's supervisor is located in a dark corner of the dormitory where the ventilation and lighting is extremely poor. The staff members of the school object strongly to this condition and at times have refused to occupy the room. It is essential that a staff member sleep in a room off the boy's dormitory. A suitable room could be arranged by moving the partition of the present room to an outside wall where the ventilation and lighting is good.

3. When the new class room building was constructed the plans thereof did not provide for a porch over the main entrance door. This door opens outward and it is not possible to make use of a storm door. During cold weather the door becomes badly frosted over, and the consequent swelling of the wood, due to moisture from the frost, prevents proper closing of the door. On windy days it is blown open and has been blown off its hinges twice. It is essential that a porch be constructed.

4. The outside toilet pans are rusted through and require repair. The local Hardware Merchant claims he is unable to procure the galvanized iron required for this purpose. It is thought that possibly this could be done through the priority rights of the Department to materials of this type. If so, it is requested that the material listed on the enclosed Form 37 be shipped as directed thereon.

Yours very truly,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith covering letter from Indian Agent S.H. Simpson and requisitions in connection with needed changes at the File Hills Indian Residential for the purpose of changing the location of the wash basins, repairing the front steps, repairing the verandah floor, moving the Boys' Supervisor's room, and material for toilet cans for outside toilets, also the construction of a porch entrance for the new classroom.

Indian Agent Simpson's letter explains the need of these changes and I would recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Attached you will find an account of Mr. S.Lecours, Lebret, Sask. dated Aug. 31st 1944 for $16.00, which is still unpaid. The original bill was wrongly made out, stating that the labour consisted of painting, and was mailed to me for payment. As Mr. Lecours had been engaged in painting at the School on about the same dates I concluded that the account was intended to cover this labour and issued a cheque on the school for payment. Later I received a letter from Mr. Lecours demanding payment for the painting he had done at the School stating that the previous cheque covered the labour he had performed for the Department in repairing and installing eave-troughs. As his bill for painting amounted to only $12.60 and our cheque was for $16.00 I have asked him to refund me the difference, ($3.40) and present the proper bill for eavetroughing to the Department for payment.

As a result of this misunderstanding over two years have elapsed, but I trust that the Department will see fit to make an adjustment.

I would appreciate very much your attention to this matter.

Yours very truly,

L. L. Dobbin

Dear Mr. Simpson;

You will recall that about a year and a half ago a jacket heater and tank was installed in the furnace room of the school. This was to replace an overhead horizontal tank which was leaking badly from a number of holes eaten out by rust all along the bottom of the tank. After consultation with a plumber who made an examination of the tank it was decided that it was unfit for further use and that a jacket heater would serve our purpose better than the overhead tank which was heated from the furnace and necessitated the keeping on of fires during warm weather, thus keeping the building too warm at this time.

Toward the end of the first year of use it was noticed that the tank heater was losing its efficiency and since early last fall it has become increasing difficult to heat sufficient water for the laundry, kitchen and washrooms. For some months it has been necessary to keep all drafts open continually in order to heat the quantity of water required. This condition results in the consumption of approximately a ton of coal per week, and with the coal shortage what it is at present it means that something must be done immediately.

The solution of the problem as I see it is to remove the old overhead tank and replace it with a new one of the same capacity and connect it up to the furnace as before. During spring, summer and fall when the furnace is not being used, water could then be heated by a jacket heater. Before doing this however, it would be necessary to remove the accumulated encrustation of scale on the inside of the jacket and pipes, if this is possible. Otherwise it would be necessary to procure a new jacket.

This matter is very urgent and I would greatly appreciate your bringing it to the attention of the Department at the earliest possible date.

Yours very truly,

L.L. Dobbin,
Principal

BY AIR MAIL
Following instructions contained in your letter dated August 13th the File Hills Indian Residential School at Balcarres was visited on September 2nd, and the Indian Agent, Mr. Simpson; the Principal, Mr. L. McLean; and the Kitchen Matron were contacted.

It was discovered during the visit that the only complaints about the water were expressed by the kitchen matron. It was her contention that the water had a disagreeable taste, which made it unfit for drinking, and excessive hardness, which made laundering and washing difficult.

The water did have a definite taste which was probably due to a high mineral content and the presence of iron compounds. However, to the writer this taste did not appear to make the water unpalatable.

Two or three commercial chemicals have been tried in an effort to soften the water on a small scale for washing and laundering. In the opinion of the kitchen matron these have not been satisfactory as they are very hard on the hands.

I explained to her that it would be difficult and relatively expensive to remove the taste and the hardness from all of the water. As a substitute I recommended that she try the different commercial products on the market that are sold as softeners so that she could discover the one most suitable for her needs. In this connection I promised to forward a list of the commercial products that are known to me.

During the visit the water system was examined and a number of water samples were collected. There appears to be little chance of this water being contaminated, but if the bacteriological reports are unfavourable the school will be revisited and an effort will be made to locate the source of the contamination.

Attached hereto is a copy of a letter from Messrs. Westeel Products Ltd., Regina, dated Nov. 17th, which is self-explanatory.

In order to install the fire escapes part of the brick walls in the dormitories of the boys and girls will have to be cut out. While this and the work of installing the fire escapes is being done, the rooms will be exposed to the winter weather. The water works in these rooms will also be exposed. It is therefore considered that this work should not be undertaken until spring.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from Indian Agent, Mr. S. H. Simpson of the File Hills Agency, together with tender and requisition for the installation of 2 fire escapes for the second floor of the main building of the File Hills Indian Residential school.

This old building would burn very quickly if it caught fire and I am not at all satisfied that the present fire escapes would be sufficient if a fire started at night. I discussed the matter with the Principal and with Mr. Simpson about two months ago, when I visited the school, and asked Mr. Simpson to make enquiries as to a suitable type of fire escape and the cost thereof. The enclosed tender and requisition is the result of Mr. Simpson's efforts in that direction.

Mr. Simpson's remarks about the difficulty in installing the new fire escapes in the winter will be noted; I now feel inclined to recommend that installation of the fire escapes be delayed until Spring, in view of the cost and the difficulty of installation at this time.

I discussed with the Principal the need for a very careful and thorough fire drill and he has taken the necessary steps to train the children and the staff towards a speedy exit, with the present escapes, until better escapes can be provided.

I am in receipt of advice from the Principal of the File Hills Residential School that the engine used for pumping water from the dug out to the school buildings is over twenty years old and worn out, and a new one is needed.

Memorandum:

Mr. Roy,

File Hills Indian Residential School -

The comments of Inspector Ostrander and Mr. Indian Agent Simpson are passed to you herewith for information.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Re: Department Letter No. 111-1-13 (W.T.) Dec. 9, 1947,
to Reverend George Dorey, D.D., File Hills Indian Residential School.

I am enclosing herewith duplicate report of Indian Agent Mr. S.H. Simpson, commenting on report of inspection of food services, etc. at the File Hills Indian Residential School. Mr. Simpson's report is quite thorough and his comments in accordance with the facts.

Much of the additional equipment, particularly that which is power driven, cannot be operated with the present electric power, and, I believe, should not be purchased until the school can be served from the power line which, it is hoped, may be possible within the next year or two. As we have been hoping for this service, I have not recommended that any large expenditure be made for a new power plant at the school.

Regarding the food supplies, Mr. McLean, the Principal, is purchasing carefully and endeavouring to provide a balanced diet for the children. This has been the subject of two discussions with Mr. McLean, and he is certainly making an honest effort to carry out the wishes of the Department and, as near as possible, provide the needs of the children in that direction.

Regarding over-crowding of the school and insufficient dormitory and recreation space, there are actually more children in the school and a larger staff than the size of the school warrants. However, I think it would be a mistake to consider building an addition to the school. An addition to the present building at this time would be a waste of money. It would constitute a dangerous building from the point of view of its fire hazard, further additions resulting in more corridors and more danger in evacuating the children in case of fire. If it is decided that a residential school is to continue to operate to accommodate the children of the File Hills Agency, a new building should be erected near the power line at a site where there is a good permanent supply of suitable water, and the building should be as near fire-proof as possible, with proper facilities for evacuation of the children.

In the last paragraph of Mr. Simpson's report he makes a recommendation that a Department engineer examine the building for advice before any considerable expenditure is made in the way of plumbing, interior painting, etc. I concur with this recommendation. It should be remembered that the water supply, sewage facilities, and power facilities are all very inadequate, and that the building is dangerous from the point of view of fire.

In less than a year two residential school buildings in this province have burned. Both were fire traps and in both cases we were fortunate that there was no loss of life. This was because every possible precaution had been taken for evacuation of the children. The File Hills School, the Round Lake School, and the St. Alban's school are all dangerous in this respect, and those responsible for their operation have to be continually on the alert day and night to avoid a great disaster.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Re- copy of Departmental Letter 111-1-13(W.F) Dec. 8/47 to Rev. George Dorsey D.D., pertaining to File Hills Indian Residential School, and received by this office.

As requested I have discussed with Mr. Lean, Principal of the school the "Report on Inspection of Food Services" which was attached to the marginally noted copy of the Departmental letter.

Supervision and Training Pupils in Cookery

The Cook, Mrs. Drake, appears to be an excellent cook, is interested in her work and has the confidence and cooperation of the girls receiving training in the work. She has a staff member assisting her during the hours the various groups of girls are receiving their training which are from 10 A.M. to 12 noon, and from 4:30 P.M. to 7:30 P.M.

Facilities

1. Covering of flooring in dining room. This matter is being referred to later on in the report.

2. Replacement and additions of cooking utensils. Items recommended are on order but are not available at present.

3. Proper dishwashing unit. It appears that an electric operated unit was recommended. The power plant at this building is not strong enough to use electric equipment. There appears to be some doubt as to the advisability of using an electric washer. Apparently stains are left on some of the dishes, and these have to be sorted out and washed by hand. The girls received no training in the method of dishwashing in the home. I examined the dishes in use, and in the cupboards, and found them spotlessly clean.

4. Walk-in refrigerator. The only place to install a refrigeration unit is located the whole length of the building from the kitchen. Due to lack of electric power a gas motor unit would have to be installed. At present ice is used for this purpose.

5. Potato Peeler. It is considered that one is not required under present conditions. In order to procure as much nourishment as possible potatoes are more often than not cooked in their jackets. When not the girls receive instruction how to properly peel and clean them.

6. Bread Slicer. One has been on order for some time, but has not yet been supplied. (Hand operated type)

7. Electric Mixer. Cannot be operated by the present electric power system.

8. Bread Mixer. A hand operated mixer is considered too heavy to do satisfactory work. There is no power to operate an electric one.

9. Rack for drying dish towels. Is on order and will be put into use as soon as received.

Sanitation and Hygiene Conditions. Floors and drab appearance of rooms throughout the school. Cost of materials and labour to improve this condition is listed in 1945-49 Estimates and will be requisitioned for in due course.

Dishwashing method though awkward appears to be sanitary. To improve the present method, also to improve working conditions, the kitchen would have to be remodelled.
Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions (cont.)

The matter of procuring a suitable cart for transporting dishes to and from the dining room is being looked into by the Principal of the School.

Water Supply. It is inadequate and not satisfactory. The water from the deep well is very hard. A fair quantity of rain water is procured from the roof of the main building. Eavestroughing should be installed on the new class room building to conserve the rain water therefrom, and another dug out installed adjacent to the school.

Untidy appearance of girls. This condition has been improved.

Food Supplies. Beef, pork, eggs, chickens, butter and milk are supplied in adequate quantities from the school farm. The garden in 1947 was a failure.

Menu Planning. A weekly menu is now being used, whereby adequate and wholesome meals are served.

Nutritional Aspects. Use of the following has been increased: liver, cheese, tomato juice and lemons.

Food Preparation, Cookery and Service. The basic 100 quantity receipts supplied to the cooks which had been removed from the school has not yet been replaced.

It is found that due to the cramped space in the staff and children's dining rooms, it is not possible to serve hot meals without some dishes getting cool. It is expected that when the extra cart for transporting dishes is brought into use, it will eliminate to some extent this condition.

General. The main school building though old appears to be very well constructed, and could be made serve its purpose for many years more by making a number of alterations.

It is badly in need of interior and exterior painting and repairs to floors, two small ceilings, verandah and steps.

The 32 volt power plant is heavily loaded. Lighting is very poor throughout all buildings including class rooms.

No electrical, portable appliances or machinery can be operated. Gas engines have to be employed within the building.

The whole water works system appears to be worn out, and has rusted through in places. It should be replaced and enlarged. There is only one bath tub for use of about 50 girls, and one for about 50 boys.

The sleeping dormitories for the pupils are both overcrowded, no space therein is provided to hang or store their wearing apparel, or bedding. Wash basins are installed against the inside wall of each dormitory and in full view.

Staff sleeping quarters are poorly arranged and inadequate. There are not sufficient rooms to employ the extra staff that is required to carry out the programme planned.

There is no recreational space for pupils or staff. The children are forced to use the stairways and main hall way for this purpose. The staff members have to crowd into the only sitting room in the building or retire to their respective rooms when off duty, with the exception of the Principal and Farming Instructor who are provided with a residence.

These conditions make it most difficult to procure and retain for any reasonable length of time, the type of employees most suited for this work.

Mr. L. McLean, Principal, appears to be a conscientious capable worker, and most anxious to see that this school renders the service for which it is intended.

It is felt that the present building could be altered and added to, to give the accommodation badly needed, and the necessary equipment installed therein at a cost that would be justified.

I recommend that if possible a Department engineer be obtained to look over this building with this view, and submit a report before any further expenditures of any great extent are made in the way of plumbing, interior painting, repairing floors, ceiling and verandah, or installing a refrigeration plant.

S.J. Simpson, Indian Agent.

Mr. Chaplin's agreement was to supply the paint and oil for the main school building, the hog house, ice house, implement shed, 3 granaries, hen house and brooder house, and to perform the labour necessary for the painting of the main school building. After the paint was delivered it was found impossible to have the labour performed on the main building under Mr. Chaplin's contract, because the weather became too severe and he had difficulty in getting the services of men to perform the work. This cannot be completed before the end of the current fiscal year.

All paint and oil having been delivered at the school in preparation for painting this year, Mr. Chaplin assures Indian Agent, Mr. S. H. Simpson, that he will carry out his part of the agreement to perform the labour in connection with the painting of the main school building at the price quoted, $256.00 for labour.

The Principal of the File Hills Residential School has advised that the old Delco Light Plant Engine at the School is worn out, and that considerable trouble is being experienced in keeping it in operation. Also that it is in constant need of repair, new parts are becoming most difficult to procure, and there is a danger of the plant failing to operate.

Attached hereto is a copy of a letter from Messrs Greenfield Motors, Balcarres, to which is attached their tender to supply, and install the type of engine and batteries needed to give the required service.

Enclosed is Form 37 listing the requirements in this connection.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from Indian Agent Mr. S.H. Simpson, of the File Hills Agency; copy of a letter from Greenfield Motors, of Balcarres; tender of Greenfield Motors; and requisition, Form 37, in connection with the installation of a new lighting plant for the File Hills Indian Residential School, at a cost of $1277.93, less salvage value of the old batteries. Mr. Greenfield does not give a quotation on this. He says he will make an allowance, depending on the unused portion of the batteries at the time the installation of the new ones takes place. I presume it will be only a small amount.

The lighting plant at the File Hills School has been giving a great deal of trouble for some time. I had delayed recommending a new plant because there seemed to be some hope that we would be able to connect the school with a Hydro at a not far distant date. However, this does not now seem very hopeful, and I would therefore recommend the acceptance of the tender of Greenfield Motors and that instructions be issued for the installation at an early date.

When Mr. C.A.F. Clarke visited the File Hills Indian Residential School recently the matter of the plumbing was brought to his attention by the Principal of the School, and as a result of their discussion the Principal called in a plumber who works with Greenfield Motors, of Balcarres, to examine and give a quotation on the work required. Herewith enclosed is report of Greenfield Motors, and estimates of some of the cost of the work.

The plumbing and sewage disposal at the File Hills School has not been in good condition for many years. If this school is to continue to operate it will certainly have to have considerable improvement in that system.

The estimates enclosed total $7,315.25 without any quotations on the sewage disposal plant. In my opinion the sewage disposal plant is the most important of the whole work and is likely to be found very costly. It would appear that in an effort to avoid having the disposal field below the school, where the water supply for the livestock and the school well are situated, the disposal field has been installed in the other direction, toward higher ground. I believe that the disposal field should be toward the lower ground, but if that is done certainly another well to supply water to the school appears a necessity. What the new disposal field and well would cost, it is almost impossible to estimate, but I would not be surprised if the figure given above would be more than doubled.

With this in mind, and a considerable doubt in my mind that a residential school is a necessity at the present site of the File Hills School, I have hesitated about making any definite recommendation pending the recommendation of the Joint Committee and the decision of Parliament on the matter of continuing the operation of a residential school to serve reserves such as the File Hills reserves, where conditions suggest day schools to me.

There is a two-classroom school on the site of the File Hills Indian Residential School which could be used as a day school by providing transportation for the children, perhaps at an average distance of six miles. The cost of renewing the plumbing and sewage at the File Hills Indian Residential School would pay for a lot of transportation of Indian pupils to a day school. Certainly the present location of this classroom building is not ideal to be operated as a day school to serve the children of that area, but, by providing transportation, it could serve for a few years until the cost of building two or three other day schools in proper locations would be a great deal less.

Many of the homes of that area from which children are sent to the File Hills Indian Residential School are good Indian homes whose parents should be expected to do something toward their education, with the assistance they now receive from family allowances. I believe also that many of the parents would be very pleased to do so.

I believe this matter should receive serious consideration by our Branch as to policy, and, if it is decided to continue operating the File Hills Indian Residential School, an engineer should be sent there to thoroughly examine the situation before anything is done about the enclosed estimate. Certainly a very important factor in carrying out this work has not been estimated upon at all. This is with regard to the sewage disposal plant. Consequently our own engineer should be asked to do some figuring on that part of the work before a decision is made.

J.P.B. Ostranier,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Sask.

Dear Sirs:

You will please find enclosed our tender for the labor and material necessary to repair the plumbing at the File Hill Res. School at Balcarres, Sask.

We have checked into this very thoroughly and must report that the plumbing in this building is in a very bad condition. I am enclosing with this letter a report on our findings, and would like to point out that this report and estimate have been made by a member of the National association of Master Plumbers. You will gather from his report that these repairs should be carried out as soon as possible. The only time this can be done without disrupting the activities would be during July and August, and in order to get this completed we would need the full two months.

Should you consider our tender we would appreciate your letting us know as soon as possible, as it will take some time to bring in the material needed.

I have included a tender in blank for the septic tank and disposal field. You will understand that until these are examined it is not possible for us to give an estimate. They may be able to be repaired, or we might have to renew them. We cannot examine them until the school closes down for holidays.

Should we be favored with this contract you may be assured of our utmost co-operation. All work will be in the hands of a master plumber.

When Mr. G.A.F. Clarke visited the File Hills Indian Residential School recently the matter of the plumbing was brought to his attention by the Principal of the School, and as a result of their discussion the Principal called in a plumber who works with Greenfield Motors, of Balcarres, to examine and give a quotation on the work required. Herewith enclosed is report of Greenfield Motors, and estimates of some of the cost of the work.

The plumbing and sewage disposal at the File Hills School has not been in good condition for many years. If this school is to continue to operate it will certainly have to have considerable improvement in that system.

The estimates enclosed total $7,315.25 without any quotations on the sewage disposal plant. In my opinion the sewage disposal plant is the most important of the whole work, and is likely to be found very costly. It would appear that in an effort to avoid having the disposal field below the school, where the water supply for the livestock and the school well are situated, the disposal field has been installed in the other direction, toward higher ground. I believe that the disposal field should be toward the lower ground, but if that is done certainly another well to supply water to the school appears a necessity. What the new disposal field and well would cost, it is almost impossible to estimate, but I would not be surprised if the figure given above would be more than doubled.

With this in mind, and a considerable doubt in my mind that a residential school is a necessity at the present site of the File Hills School, I have hesitated about making any definite recommendation pending the recommendation of the Joint Committee and the decision of Parliament on the matter of continuing the operation of a residential school to serve reserves such as the File Hills reserves, where conditions suggest day schools to me.

There is a two-classroom school on the site of the File Hills Indian Residential School which could be used as a day school by providing transportation for the children, perhaps at an average distance of six miles. The cost of renewing the plumbing and sewage at the File Hills Indian Residential School would pay for a lot of transportation of Indian pupils to a day school. Certainly the present location of this classroom building is not ideal to be operated as a day school to serve the children of that area, but, by providing transportation, it could serve for a few years until the cost of building two or three other day schools in proper locations would be a great deal less.

Many of the homes of that area from which children are sent to the File Hills Indian Residential School are good Indian homes whose parents should be expected to do something toward their education, with the assistance they now receive from Family Allowances. I believe also that many of the parents would be very pleased to do so.

I believe this matter should receive serious consideration by our Branch as to policy, and, if it is decided to continue operating the File Hills Indian Residential School, an engineer should be sent there to thoroughly examine the situation before anything is done about the enclosed estimates. Certainly a very important factor in carrying out this work has not been estimated upon at all. This is with regard to the sewage disposal plants. Consequently our own engineer should be asked to do some figuring on that part of the work before a decision is made.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Sask.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 24th instant, File No. 111-1-5 (§), in connection with the File Hills Indian Residential School and the matter of substitution of a day school for the residential school.

With regard to that part of the Department letter which refers to transportation and roads, I have to say that it is my opinion that horse drawn vehicles should be used. It will probably be many years before the roads in that area are suitable for year round use of motor transport. With school commencing the 1st of September, and the roads usually closing for motor transport any time after the middle of October, not re-opening again until the month of May, the investment cost of motor transport to serve our purpose would be prohibitive.

It is my opinion that there should be two Indians hired with driving teams and that each be supplied with a wheel vehicle and a bob sleigh, with a suitable covered cabin which could be used on either the wheels or the bob sleigh. This cabin should be provided with a wood heater for cold weather. The cost of operation of the two outfits should not exceed $3,000.00 a year, and two dependable Indians would be glad to have the employment.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Repairs and Alterations at File Hills School

In the absence of Dr. Dorey I am taking the liberty of presenting some matters which were drawn to my attention during my recent visit in Saskatchewan.

A year ago we appointed Mr. Lachlan McLean as Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School. Mr. McLean's first year of work can be very highly commended but in order that he may successfully carry on there are very necessary improvements which need to be given attention. These matters have been discussed with the Indian Agent and have, no doubt, come to you from your Saskatchewan representative, but I should like to assure you that if we are going to maintain the high standard of work which has been previously done there is great need for these expenditures:

1) A complete new water system. When I visited the school two years ago I urged our Principal at that time to have new bathroom equipment installed, new floors in the rooms used, and all the pipes replaced. There was also a need for wash rooms in the basement or on the first floor in order that the children might not have to return to the dormitories to wash up for meals;

2) The Play-Rooms - are very badly in need of new floors and the battleship linoleum covering the halls is worn through and needs replacing immediately;

3) Re-arrangement of Basement rooms - If you have ever been in this school you will recall that the cook walks approximately 75 feet from the kitchen to the supply room for her groceries, therefore, the re-arrangement of the basement rooms and the provision of more space for play-rooms is urgently needed;

4) A new lighting system - should be installed, and while I was at the school an engineer arrived to make some arrangements about the water system which again you may remember is pumped from a slough but a new dug-out is necessary in order that sufficient pressure may be obtained;
Colonel Neary - 2 -

5) Re. Painting - Looking at the fine condition of the buildings at the Agency and then the drab appearance of our school buildings we were agreed that a general paint job is also necessary and desirable.

Considering the amount of work involved, $12,000.00 does not seem a large sum for these expenditures and I can assure you that Mr. McLean will use every dollar to advantage.

Re. Agency Houses

With the difficulty in securing staff it has now become apparent that we must employ married men and with only one residence for assistants it is sometimes difficult to make suitable living accommodation for the type of staff which may be secured. Since the Agency will now have two vacant houses Mr. McLean is very anxious that these houses may be moved sufficiently close to the school to be used for the employees. When this matter comes to your attention may I assure you that there is a definite need for the establishment of these buildings as employee houses.

I had a most satisfactory visit in Fule Hills where I found the children extremely friendly, in good physical condition and in great glee because of their anticipated return home.

With my kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. C. Maxwell Loveys
Home Mission Executive Secretary.
