Attention of Mr. Neary,

The following quotation is taken from Certificate of Inspection of pressure boiler No. 15335 at the File Hills Indian Residential School for an inspection which took place on July 10th, 1948, by the Inspector of Steam Boilers, Department of Labour:

"Install an equalizer pipe and new return water pipe. Boilers require a blow down tank and blow down valves so that boilers may be cleaned. This boiler must not be put into operation until the above work is completed and notice of such forwarded to this Department. These boilers should be replaced by a modern stoker unit."

At the request of the then Indian Agent, Mr. S.H. Simpson, a tender was received from Greenfield Motors dated June 4th, 1948, for the following:

"Supply and install blow off tank and valves, all pipes and fittings, to renew return lines from end of mains to boilers and install equalizers in each boiler. Complete cost of labour and material $797.60."

This was one of the many expenditures necessary to put the File Hills Residential School in reasonably good working order, which resulted in my decision to write my letter of June 15th, 1948, File 1094-311-11 A.U., in which I questioned the wisdom of incurring large expenditures at that school and mentioned that consideration might be given to replacing the residential school by one or more day schools. I have received Department letter dated June 19th, 1948, File 111-1-5 (E.1), to the effect that the File Hills Residential School will operate for at least another academic year.

In view of the fact that the boiler, in its present condition, has been condemned, it is very necessary that authority be given at once to have the repairs completed on the boiler before the school opens, or as soon as possible thereafter. Mr. Booth has recently spoken to Greenfield Motors in connection with their tender, as mentioned above. The completed work on which they have tendered will no doubt meet the requirements of the boiler inspector's order. Mr. Greenfield is prepared to make the installation at the price he quoted on July 4th, 1948.

Mr. Booth has received authority from the Department under letter dated July 21st, 1948, File 111-1-5 (E.1), to proceed with certain minor repairs and additions, and this work will proceed. The work on the boiler, as mentioned before, is even more urgent.

I would recommend that Mr. Booth be authorized by telegram to instruct Greenfield Motors to proceed at once with the work.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

File Hills Residential School

(1) REPAIRS:

By now you will have received an Army Signal concerning the boiler repairs and the purchase of the lighting plant required at the above residential school.

The Minister has approved the acceptance of the tender of Greenfield Motors Limited, to the amount of $797.60 to carry out the repairs as listed in their tender of June 4th, 1948.

Yesterday we mailed a copy of purchase order 33063 covering the purchase of a lighting plant and a set of batteries from Greenfield Motors Limited.

(2) FUTURE POLICY WITH REGARD TO THE OPERATION OF THIS SCHOOL:

Two days ago, Dr. Dorsey of the United Church of Canada visited this office. The contents of your letter of June 15th was discussed with him at some length and while not committing himself fully, it seems fairly evident that he is in agreement with the replacement of this residential school by day schools.

Major Clark was also present at the discussion and he too is in agreement with your recommendation. It
is understood that the two class room school block now on the site of the residential school could be used as a day school, providing transportation for the children could be arranged. It was, therefore, agreed that Major Clark would visit the school this fall and go over the roads thoroughly and decide whether bus transportation is feasible. It would be appreciated if efforts could be made to improve the roads selected to the extent required for them to be used by a heavy school bus. Our experiences with such transportation in Ontario have convinced us that good roads are essential for the provision of adequate school bus transportation.

I also understand that another day school would be required on this reserve near the File Hills colony. Would it be possible to have arrangements made for the school children at the File Hills colony to be admitted to the provincial school at Lerlie?

To summarize, therefore -

(1) File Hills Residential School will be operated as a residential school during the 1948-49 academic year.

(2) A thorough survey will be completed to decide what day school facilities can be provided to replace this residential school during the 1949-50 academic year.

(3) Before the closing of this residential school is authorized, adequate educational facilities must be ready to provide for the continuance of the education of these children. In other words, we cannot close the residential school until the day schools required are complete and bus transportation is provided.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Recently, the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church received a request from their leaders in Saskatchewan for $1500, with which to clear 100 acres of land in the vicinity of File Hills, that is now the property of our Church and that is being used in connection with the File Hills work.

Our W.M.S. have 420 acres. 70 acres of this is under cultivation. Of this 70 acres, 48 have been cropped in wheat and oats and have been worked for years without rest. 10 acres is used for potatoes and the remainder is practically useless owing to timber and potholes. The fuel for the school has always been taken from this property.

The proposal now made is that 100 acres of the 420 shall be cleared. It appears that there is a man nearby who has a machine and is willing to do this work at $15.00 per acre, which will mean in all, $1500. I understand that Mr. Graham and Mr. Rhodes met in conference with the W.M.S. representatives in Regina, before this request was made, so it is quite evident that Mr. Graham approves the suggestion.

The matter has been taken up by the Board of the W.M.S. and as the Society has no money to apply on this work, it was decided to ask the Government to vote $1500 for the purpose. If the Department is not willing to expend money on land that does not belong to the Government, then the W.M.S. will be willing to sell the 100 acres at a very reasonable price. Or, they will be willing to sell the 420 acres, if the Government would prefer to take the whole farm.

Hoping for a favorable reply, believe me

Yours sincerely,

JHE/HC
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., D.Litt., F.R.S.C.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have yours of July 12th re the purchase by the Government of the W. M. S. property at File Hills. There seems to be some misunderstanding. The facts are as follows:

1. Our W. M. S. own the S. E. 1/4 Sec. of 32, Tp. 22, Rangell W.E., comprising 160 acres. You speak of this as a free gift from the Government. While this was referred to as a free gift by Mrs. Jones in her letter of May 17th, copy of which I sent you, this is a little misleading. This quarter section was homesteaded by a friend of our Principal, now Mrs. Motherwell and was later transferred to our Women's missionary Society with the approval of the Government. Homestead duties were done according to law. This seems to me as a little different from a free gift and the W. M. S. should be entitled to any increase in value, as property homesteaded by any private individual.

The other property owned by the W. M. S. is the West half of Sec. 33 comprising 253.35 acres for which they paid $3 per acre or $760.65. Mrs. Clark informs me that their Society through their Solicitor Dr. Hamilton Cassels, appealed to the Government at different times for a free gift. This was not allowed however, and they were obliged to pay $3 per acre. In the judgment of the W. M. S. it is worth more today either to the church or Department.

The N. E. 1/4 Sec. of 32, comprising 151.42 acres referred to in your letter of the 13th is included in this 253.35 acres. From this you will see that the W. M. S. own in all only 412.35. They feel that they should get at least $3,000. for this property.

Kindly let me know if the Department is prepared to buy at this price.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott.

There is an item of $1,500 in the Estimates for clearing additional land at the File Hills Indian Residential School. Mr. Commissioner Graham writes, asking if there is an appropriation for this purpose as the work, if to be undertaken, should be commenced immediately. I wish to recommend that $1,000 be allowed for this purpose and that the Commissioner be asked to undertake the activity on a day labour basis, using Indians.

Russell Harrier

Ottawa, April 21st, 1926.

Sir:

I have your No. 306-11 A of the 17th instant, requesting to be advised as to whether an appropriation can be allowed for the purpose of clearing additional land at the File Hills Indian Residential School in order that the management can increase the area of their farming operations.

In reply I beg to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding $1,000 for this purpose. You should arrange to have the work undertaken on a day labour basis, using Indian labour as far as possible. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, of the labour employed should be kept. These should be certified in the usual manner.

I regret we will be unable to make an advance to pay wages at the present time. It is expected, however, that additional money will be voted shortly and will be available early next month, and if you should require an advance to pay the labour the same will be sent upon request.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

On the 21st April last, your letter No. 111-1-9, you granted me authority to expend $1000.00 in clearing land at the File Hills Boarding School. I was unable to get this work done during the summer as it was most difficult to get men to do this kind of work, owing to the fact that it requires men with some experience. I had made arrangements to have the work done by a certain party in July, but he failed me, and when harvesting operations came on it was impossible to get men unless we paid them $7.00 or $8.00 a day, which I did not think it wise to do. I was hoping to get some of the heavier scrub out this winter, but the snow has been very deep and it would only be a waste of money to attempt this work.

I write to let you know that this $1000.00 will be available for the current year's expenses, and would ask you to have a similar amount placed at my disposal next Spring.

I was not able to get as much scrubbing done at the Gordon School in the Touchwood Agency as I should have liked. So far about $200.00 of the amount of $300.00 allowed for this work has been made use of, and I should be glad if I could have $100 or $150.00 additional for this purpose out of next year's appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

I have received a request from Mrs. Emile Dubois, of the Muscowpetung Band, this Agency, that her son, Duncan Shingoose of Cote Band, who is now attending the Birtle Protestant School, be transferred to the File Hills School.

The mother of the boy, whose maiden name was Lizzie Mentuck, was a member of Cote Band, Kamsack Agency. The boy was born to her before her marriage to Dubois, and after this took place she evidently gave the child to her mother, Mrs. John Shingoose, but I cannot tell if any papers were drawn up or not.

Mrs. John Shingoose is willing to have the boy transferred to the File Hills school and has made a statement to that effect which I enclose herewith.

The boy is now 11 years of age, and of course if transferred to File Hills School, would be able to spend his holidays with his mother, with practically no expense to the Department. At the present time both he and his grandmother are staying with Mrs. Emile Dubois, and if the transfer could be arranged, it would cost the Department nothing to have him taken to the File Hills school, otherwise his fare would have to be paid back to Birtle.

It would seem to me that the request is very reasonable, and I would ask the Department to give it favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I beg to inform the Department that John Archie Squatipew, aged 14 years, a pupil of the File Hills School, placed a quantity of paper and wood on the pipes at the back of the furnace in the school where it would have ignited if a big fire had been made. He also placed some paper and wood on the floor underneath the pipes so that the burning embers would fall and set fire to the paper on the floor. The Engineer discovered what had been done almost immediately after the boy had left the furnace room, and the Principal informs me that on questioning the boy he admitted that he was going to try and burn down the school so that they could get a holiday. There was really very little danger of this doing damage even had his plan worked out, as there is a cement wall and metallic ceiling and no refuse is left lying around. However the intent was there and Mr. Rhodes, the Principal, punished the boy by giving him a strapping on his hands.

This boy is of very low mentality; as a matter of fact he cannot be considered normal. The Principal feels very strongly that he should receive further punishment and suggested that he be sent to the Detention Home in Regina as an example to the others. I have received a strong plea for leniency from the Agent. It appears that the aged parents of this boy are taking the matter very much to heart, as they feel that he is not altogether responsible, and I would be glad to have the Department's views in the matter.

Personally, I feel that discharging him and sending him home would not meet the situation. In fact it might act as an incentive to other boys to attempt the same thing in order to bring about their discharge from the school. My suggestion is that the boy be sent to either Round Lake, Gordon's, or Elkhorn Schools for a month or two and then discharged if thought advisable. This

Division or Dist.

Sir,

I have the honour to forward herewith certificates of health and application for the admission to the Pine Mills Residential School of Lucy Hilda Bear and Lena Bear, children of Mrs. Rose Bear Gendreau pay ticket No. 153 John Smith's Band this Agency.

In the year 1919 Rose Bear daughter of Henry Bear No. 83 John Smith's Band, married Edward Gendreau a half-breed a labourer of Prince Albert Sask. She lived with her husband at Prince Albert for a short time, then left him because she claims he was a drunkard and cruel to her; she returned to her reserve to her former (parents) home, with whom she remained for some time, then left there and went to live with Gilbert James Bear, pay ticket No. 22, a widower a returned soldier, on the reserve. The two children Lucy Hilda and Lena were born to her, while she lived with Gilbert James Bear, who she states is the father, and which he admitted. I placed both children's names on the Annuity pay sheets on their mother's ticket No. 153.

On December 3rd 1926 Gilbert James Bear was legally married to Widow Maud Gendreau No. 111 James Smith's Band, with whom he still lives.

The woman Rose Bear Gendreau then again went to live with her parents, bringing her two children with her; she is still living with her father who is now a widower, her mother having died in April 1931.

The Bears are very poor and the mother (Rose) cannot provide properly for her children.

I recommend that the application be approved.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Re: Lena, Fred & Philomena TANNER (Juveniles) - Truant Indians, Yorkton, Saskatchewan.

---

28-9-33.

1. Approximately 2:40 p.m. of this date, P.G. LAZENBY, the agent for the Indian Reserve of Birtle, Manitoba called at this detachment and reported that the three above named juveniles had run away from the C.M.R. passenger train at this point, that the three above named were entrained for Balcarres, Saskatchewan where they were to attend the Indian school. Their respective ages being 16, 14 & 8 yrs. He further stated that these children after leaving the train had called at one of the houses west of the station where they got a drink of water and then continued west. He requested assistance of the police in locating these juveniles.

2. Obtaining the description in detail and pursuant to instructions received from Det. Corp. Woods of Yorkton C.I.B., I immediately patrolled per Constable Parsons' P/Auto to the section of the city where they were last seen. I inquired at John KORUT's residence where they obtained a drink of water and there I learned that the boy mentioned about hiding on KORUT's premises but the elder girl decided to keep going. They continued another block south and then turned west. I continued searching along this route but failed to learn anything further. I continued patrol west and then proceeded to search the bush on the outskirts west of the city without results. Then I continued patrol to the first road west of the city and notify all the farmers along this road, and continued on road north of the city with the same results. After a general search of two hours, I got in touch with the detachment and learned that these children had been picked up by the Indian agent east of Yorkton. I returned to detachment.

3. About 9:15 p.m. of the same date, P.H. BLANCH from the Indian School at Balcarres called at this detachment. I duly handed these juveniles over to him, obtaining receipt for same which is on file at this office, and escorted them to Balcarres same p.m.

In reply to your No. 15 of the 13th instant, I beg to say that, provided she is not in excess of the number for which grant is allowed, you may inform the Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School that the admission of Lilian Marjory Fiddler is approved.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
